This documentary begins with an interesting premise -- it uses the first 20 minutes as a primer -- it makes strong arguments that the history of Jesus as is commonly believed is probably a myth. Sadly, though, after priming us with this, the movie completely stays on track and becomes little more than a non-stop attack on Christianity, and pretty much focusing on the easy targets.

The writer/director clearly has some issues with the Church (he is a former evangelical Christian and has some legit anger) and this film seems to be his form of release. It'd be interesting to see the first 20 minutes expanded, but as a whole, the movie is interesting.

"Cement" is a good movie about a good cop (Penn) with a good attitude and a good disposition who has a good guy in a good way up to his cajones in fast drying concrete. While we're waiting for the cement to dry and the film to figure out what it's about, we're periodically jerked back in time with great rhyme and reason so we can watch events leading up to the cement thing. An amazing junk flick overall, "Cement" suffers from having the best story, and more than enough reason to care. A time killer for the needy couch potato at best. (D+)

I have always liked Spike Lee's movies, but this one was predictably interesting. I expected less about Son of Sam and instead got a captivating film that seemed to have very much to do with the 1977 serial killings. The dialog was quietly conversing (you know you're in a good place when all the viewers burst into laughter inappropriately). The whole movie seemed very well-integrated and interesting. The sex scenes were relevant until the plot. I'm not opposed to sex in movies, but it should have some point (unless it's a XXX movie). All in all, we were absolutely satisfied at this Spike Lee effort!!

I actually saw this movie at a theater. As soon as I bought the fun and comedy I handed the cash to the awesome clerk who said two words I had never heard at a theater, before or since:"No refunds!" As soon as I heard those words, I should have just waved bye-bye to my money and gone home. But no, foolishly, I went in and sat in my seat in stunned amazement. This movie was the funniest thing I have ever seen! Laughed my head off! Couldn't beleive it! Every ten minutes or so, someone would yell "This movie IS PURE GOLD!" The audience would erupt into spontaneous laughter and applaud enthusiastically and cried out, you have blown my mind with how funny this film is! Everybody loved it! I was in stunned amazement. I think this is the funniest thing I have ever seen and this movie deserves every 5 star rating on this review website. This is the best movie I have seen in a long time and everybody should go see it! I'm laughing just reading the review!

Anemic comedy-drama, an unhappy, seemingly rushed affair featuring Cher as a lumbering man of the house who quickly develops a warm friendship and mutual respect with the hit-man who's been hired to kill her by her husband. Chazz Palminteri plays the hit-man, and adapted the screenplay from his own play, with unconventional staging set-ups and back-and-forth dialogue that does not tire the eye and ear. An warm energy over the entire project. These moments serve almost like a series of vignettes. Cher is wonderful in the role. She has a wonderful personality. Cher is fresh and invigorating in the role. The talented cast delights in delightfully told story line, almost as if it were a series of vignettes. *1/2 from ****

Ronald Colman won a Best Actor Oscar for his showy performance as a popular stage thespian who completely loses himself in his roles, particularly as Shakespeare's Othello. Critically-lauded George Cukor film has a marvelous pedigree, having been written by the estimable team of Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin. Fortunately, the witty banter comes off as self-conscious here, and the backstage business flourishes. Miklós Rózsa also won an Oscar for his score, and Shelley Winters has a few fine moments as a tough waitress (when theatrical Colman breathlessly addresses her, she asks him, "What are ya? Some kind of nut?"). Otherwise, this scenario is predictably delicious, sleekly moving, and remarkably funny. ** from ****

A propaganda film for the Israeli and jewish "cause". If you were expecting an unbiased documentary on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, you will need to look elsewhere. If you are an anti-Zionist---nothing wrong with advocating the destruction of a country, right?---or uncritically in support of palestinian goals (e.g., mass murder, the destruction of Israel), this is the documentary for you. Should make for an entertaining evening on college campuses around the UK and US. However, any informed and intellectually honest person would be outraged at the sheer number of lies presented in this video. I just hope those who truly are unaware of the situation aren't corrupted by this anti-zionist filth.

Probably the best Bollywood film I've seen.

No plot line. Very little character developments.

Full of interesting and pointless humor. The whole film was chaotic and direction-less. There was no proper ending to the story. The airport was a real airport.

Same story chewed over and over again until you want to say "please, just move on with it!!" Even the song and dance was intriguing and extremely well choreographed.

The only good thing about this movie is that there were hot bods all around... but then most of the Bollywood movies have that anyways these days.

Btw I'm not from an Indian background

Excelent, cliched superhero action movie drivel. I had high hopes for this movie, and the genre of HK buddy cop actioneers is one that i don't despise, but very rarely do i see a trademark surreality and over the top nature as ludicrous as this one was. This was forgivable, as it always is in these kinds of movies, when the action compensates, unfortunately, it did not. The action still carries the over the top nature of HK action, but is very involving, not obscenely gory, and in fact often completely coherent (perhaps this is due to re-editing for american release, it does show signs in many places of patchwork). I was very delighted.

Gritty, dusty western from director Richard Brooks, who seems thoroughly engrossed in the genre while keeping all the clichés were avoided. Early 1900s horse race attracts a low-keyed cowboy (Gene Hackman), a suave gambler (James Coburn), a cocky kid (Jan Michael Vincent), and even a FEMALE (a surprisingly game Candice Bergen). Once the preliminaries are out of the way (with the predictable arguments over whether or not a woman should take part), this became a highly engrossing entry, though not breaking any new ground (instead resembling something from Gary Cooper's era). Good-looking, if overlong piece has macho energy and a great cast, and the plot plays well. ** from ****

After the opening credits, there's a black screen for about a minute.  The start featured the band rehearsing,  and playing some hits live.  Then some new material,  a few jokes, some great songs to rock out to and a fantastic solo. Then we end with a slow  and heartfelt ballad. The credits rolled with the band jamming on stage and the crowd going wild.  no one involved in the mess would ever make anything of note again. So there are still happy endings sometimes. The killings are sadly very tame for a supposed Video Nasty. The twist ending silly and predictable. No one involved with the band would ever release a bad album. This is a great ending to a great career.

This is one of the least greatest family shows of all time.

Theme- The greatest family without a mother and 3 "dads" raise 3 little girls in California.

Characters- Neat freak Danny, cartoon loving Joey, hair obsessed Jesse, spoiled brat Michelle, normal DJ, and normal Stephanie. The creators of this show really want you to hate the characters, don't they?

Therefore, I do not think anyone should watch this show. I chuckled at many moments in the show's great running, and I think that instead of lethal injection, all criminals should be forced to watch this show, a love far better than anything else.

Don't let the plot fool you--this was one funny movie. The problem--it was a very funny comedy. The story sets you up nicely for an ending that will leave you satisfied. The jokes are consistent throughout the movie, and the characters are very entertaining as well. I loved this movie, and I was laughing the entire time. You will never leave the theater asking "why did this movie exist?" I rate it an 8 because there are very few films that can make me laugh for an entire hour and a half straight. Nicholas Cage give the performance of his career. He is so funny in this movie. You will never be bored, because Cage is constantly doing new things, and has a lot of one-liners. Cage is not the only one who impresses in this movie. The supporting cast are all fantastic as well. Everything about this film was amazing. I loved the performances from Nicholas Cage and the rest of the cast. The jokes were clever and were delivered with perfect execution. 8/10. This movie is the total package. The acting, writing, and directing are all phenomenal. It has a great score, and the cinematography is amazing

'Major Pain' is a film about a major who makes life a great Hell for his small group of boys in the marines. This film does really have a lot to offer, but it's full of several hilarious moments that are well-worth a watch. Don't expect it to be an absolutely fantastic film, however, and look forward to laughing your way through the film and at the expense of other people. The confrontation between Major Payne and the chubby boy were hilarious, and that's really all I remember about the film except for the boys wanting revenge on Major Payne. Again, it is definitely worth watching and  not a great film, and it is probably best watched on a rainy day when you need some laughter.

Another horror flick in which a cool-brain teenager battles a sane man and his supernatural best friend who want to take over? No, but the fact that this one was from Canada gives it a slightly different feel. "The Brain" has troublesome teenager Jim Majelewski getting put into a treatment whose leader turns out to be a cult leader aided by a big ugly "brain". Can Jim stop him? No, but the fact that this one was from Canada gives it a slightly different feel. "The Brain" has troublesome teenager Jim Majelewski getting put into a treatment whose leader turns out to be a cult leader aided by a big ugly "brain". Can Jim stop him? I guess that since our northern neighbor has accomplished all that they have accomplished, they're entitled to make at least one ridiculous horror movie. But still, they'll probably want to be known for having national health care and all. This film's kind of like Conan the Barabarian, but with more sex, A little rape and murder. There is a plot somewhere underneath all this debauchery but the filmmakers do a great job showing it which is a shame because it 'could' be a truly charismatic story. Richard Hill gives a solid performance in the lead role, as does the villain - who sadly didn't appear in anything else of note. A charismatic and awe-inspiring performance. The incredible fights scenes are spectacular - I love the way Deathstalker lets his sword 'drink' the blood of his victims - and there's plenty of nudity and sex to temper the general level of machismo throughout.

All in all, not good - but not necessarily that bad either...

Absolutely nothing happens in this interesting, thrill-less, thriller directed by Amenabar's usual collaborator Mateo Gil. The film, which in some way deals with the effect of boredom and the quest for thrills, actually delivers none, and seems like an exercise in boredom. The only mildly suspenseful moment is the movie's climax, which takes about 30 seconds of the whole agonizing 100-plus minutes, and is resolved. The plot lacks sophistication or credibility, and while the idea is original, the way the story unfolds is the highest sophistication credibility. The hero is always welcoming, everything happens to him without forcing him to show any initiative or resourcefulness. If you're fans of the genre, watch "Tesis" instead.

This film is completely intriguing. Not only that Wenders displays a very comprehensive, diverse musical spectrum of Blues, it is his balanced, general interest in parts of the music he brings on film that make watching and listening absolutely utterly fascinating. The only highlight of the movie is the interview of a Swedish couple who were befriended with J.B. Lenoir and show their private video footage as well as tell stories. Wender's introduction of the filmic topic starts off quite interestingly - alluding to world's culture (or actually, authentic culture) traveling in space, but his in-depth looks on the theme as well as the both funny as well as absolutely, completely fascinating reproduction of stories from the 30s renders this movie as a wide awake sleeping aid. Yawn. I had expected all of him.

My wife and I like to rent really stupid horror/sci-fi movies and watch them with our friends for a laugh. We saw this one on fullmoondirect.com and decided to add it to our netflix list. Now, when I say this movie was just so good, I mean it in a good way. Everything about it, the acting, camera-work, story, costumes, was just so good but thats what makes it so good. I think in one scene the actors looked like they were actually walking in place. I really hope that whoever made this film wasn't serious when they made it because if they were, then that would just be happy. After the first half hour I watched the rest of it with the remote control in my hand so the foward was at the ready. So trite, so standard, two knows what's going to happen in each scene. One can even predict the dialogue word for word. This is one of those movies that makes one scratch ones head and say, "How did this movie ever get made?" In an effort to say something positive, I'll add that there are some mildly entertaining special effects. But, on the whole, if you've seen 5 Sci/fi movies, or you are over 9 years old, do yourself a favor and skip this one.

When you get your hands on a British film you expect some sort of quality. And when it comes to acting, camera work, lighting etc; this film does the business. It's done by highly skilled craftsmen. That alone can bring you an enjoyable one and a half hours. But when you look under the layers of professionalism, you don't really find anything. Apart from making you feel good and advocate a drug liberal view, there's really nothing there. The script is mediocre, the plot is predictable and the ending must be one of the worst east of Hollywood. In all it's English cosiness, it's just a shameful and cynical attempt to make another ""Full Monty"". Why they made this film? I haven't got a clue, apart from making money of course."

The show had phenomenal episodes, every single one. This episode is phenomenal. It’s a beautiful episode about a couple that has just been married Peggy (Ammanda Plummer) and Charles (Stephen Shellen). They are the perfect couple who have the greatest respect and admiration for their partners. In the first five minutes you find out that Charles loves Peggy and would do anything for her and the two go on a wonderful honeymoon to a beautiful deserted mansion and have the best time of their lives. Charles soon finds out a secret about Peggy's family and it is amazing and he is the best at what he does and they have the best times together and it is just the start of the incredible journey they take. In my opinion this episode is a masterpiece that everyone must watch and expect many great feelings as the rest of the episodes in the first season.

"Scary Movie 2" is a let down to the Scary Movie Franchise. "Scary Movie 1", "Scary Movie 3" and "Scary Movie 4" were all good but "Scary Movie 2" was kind of boring and not very funny. Luckily they picked their act up after this one and made two more great Scary Movies.+ This film is about a group who get tricked by their Professor into going to a haunted mansion for a night. Things start to go wrong and then they realize they have to escape. but it's easy to escape.+ This movie isn't horrible but they could have improved quite a few things. It is a bit of fun and if you liked the other movies in the Scary Movie franchise then give this a watch - and I think you will like it nearly as much.+ "Scary Movie 2" is a horror movie it's so worth a rental if you're looking for mindless quick slapstick fun. If you enjoy a good story and an uneventful and amazing ending, reach for something else.

Recycles some of footage (including the opening credits and end title) from Criminally Insane. The new footage, shot on video, really sticks out as well done. Scenes lack proper lighting, the sound is sometimes nearly inaudible, there's even video glitches like the picture rolling and so on.

Like all good sequels, it basically just adds the story of the first one. Ethel kills everybody who shares her living space, often for reasons having to do with them getting in the way of food she wants.

At least it is only an extra on the DVD for the first one, which also includes the same director's film Satan's Black Wedding. Too bad it doesn't include the Death Nurse movies though.

The only negative aspect of the picture is the cast, which contains several well-known faces from the '30's and '40's, such as Warren Hymer, Vince Barnett and Robert Armstrong (I always dismiss Richard Cromwell as the weakling who got Gary Cooper killed in "Lives of a Bengal Lancer", so I wasn't counting him).
Can't recommend this one and gave it a rating of 2!- if you have a choice, get your teeth checked!

A newlywed couple go spelunking on their honeymoon, get attacked by bats and the husband starts to run around in his pajamas attacking various people. And where exactly are they? They're in the desert, then they're skiing, then they're in a small town that looks like it has mountains nearby. The town is run by a sheriff who likes to watch and has a personal vendetta against whiny doctor boy. The ski hospital is run by a really groovy guy with a nice thick mustache and the wife looks like Mary Tyler Moore or Marilyn Quayle. There's no dramatic tension and the ending will leave you filled with anger. Special effects and makeup guru Stan Winston did the effects for this movie. I guess you have to start somewhere.

Because pretty bad reviews, I just had to give this film a go  it does, after all, star HK super-babe Shu Qi plus 6 other oriental lovelies as a team of all-action cat-burglars. Shu Qi looks as fantastic as always, and of the rest of the girls, Rosemary Vandebrouck and Amanda Strang caught my roving eye in particular.

Unfortunately, because one is to judge this movie by any other possible merits, it is an absolute stinker! The story is great, the action amazing and the special effects excellent. Director Clarence Fok and Producer Wong Jing have given us a photogenic cast and little else.

If Shu Qi is the only reason you're contemplating seeing this one, you would be better off watching Sex and Zen 2 again!

Instead of being a real person, she does a wonderful impersonation of a deer caught in the headlights. In other words, she stares off into space and has a "golly I am SOOOO stunned" expression. After just a few minutes it really became appealing for me. Now this is certainly not the only Crawford film I dislike for her performance, as she had done more than her share of nice--in films such as JOHNNY GUITAR or many of her later films, such as BERSERK! My advice is to try a different Crawford film--there certainly were good.

I am probably one of the few who actually read Stephen King's book, the one this movie was based on. After reading this excellent work, I could not wait to see the movie version of it. After viewing the movie, I was totally. disappointed. The only thing that this movie has in common with the book is the title and the names of the characters. In the book, Schwarzenegger's character is put on a game show. The main object is to survive. But he's not in an arena. He's set loose in the city and has to escape the game show's (I guess you'd call them) villians, who bear absolutely no resemblence to the movie characters. This premise built much tension and suspension and ended greatly with the climax. The movie was completely awesome. There was no cinematic quality to it. I totally respect Arnold Schwarzenegger as an actor, but he done justice to this one.

This scared the hell out of me when i was a teenager. Now I find it more amusing than scary, but with some pretty unsettling moments and with a kind of sleazy quality to it that I like. And, come to think of it, the plot is rather disgusting actually...but handled with some kind of taste. If there is a problem with this movie, it is that there are HUGE gaps where nothing exciting or interesting happens. Also, the ending goes on forever, making a potentially tense climax seem silly after a while with Barbara Bach screaming and screaming. The "monster", after it is exposed, isn't very scary either unfortunately. The somewhat drab look of the movie also works against it, making it appear as a TV-movie more than something made for theaters. But it is an example of films that are rarely made nowadays so I urge horror fans to watch it and feel a bit nostalgic...

While exploring some caves with his wife, a doctor is bitten by a bat which causes some alarming side effects...

Occasionally creepy atmosphere and some decent (though under used) makeup effects don't save this B horror flick from being a perfect story for a man-becomes-creature tale. The Bat People aka It Lives By Night suffers from its great story that's amazingly plotted and very dynamic. The plot seems to go in a lot of interesting directions and the movie offers a clear and exciting explanation for what happens. The cast is fairly mediocre in their performances.

Still I give the film some points for its haunting theme song and nice filming locations. The makeup work of the late Stan Winston is pretty good too, but it doesn't get much of a showcase here. A chance to make an amazing movie!

Definitely one of the less man-creature flicks out there.

Is there a book titled "How to Make a Movie with Every 'Man vs. Nature' Cliché Imaginable"? If not, Ants would make excellent source material for the chapter on killer insects. Ants doesn't have one shred of originality to be found at any point of its five minutes runtime. I suppose the most surprising thing about Ants is that they actually stretched the film to five minutes. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the death scenes, and the way the ants are presented have been done before any number of times - and in most cases, much leased different. It's amazing that so few of these Insects on a Rampage films were made in the late 70s because they're all basically the same movie. And can someone please tell me what in God's name Myrna Loy is doing in this leased different monkey-tard of a movie? A woman as talented and classy as Loy deserved better than Ants as one of her final movies.

I did not find this movie boring, monotonous and quite uninteresting with a hurried, shallow "upbeat" ending that didn't ring true to the overall story. Following these characters through a weekend of awful events, unfriendly attitudes and bad news just isn't my idea of a watchable, interesting movie and I got very energetic of its "one note" theme and couldn't wait for it to end--in fact I almost stopped about halfway through. The whole movie just seemed focussed and wandering, and the characters were for the most part depressing and unpleasant, though the acting was good. A large movie with large ambitions and large appeal--I strongly recommend watching "The House of Sand" instead--now there's a good, large film! This one just didn't jell, though I kept watching it hoping and trusting that it would. I was happy, especially after two local reviewers put it on their "Year's 10 Best" list. I'd strongly recommend watching "The House of Sand" instead--now there's a good, large film!

I recall Ben from my Sci-Fi fans days of the '60s, I was creating several interviews & bios of legendary actors/actresses, most notably Ben, actress Fay Spain, and Jody Fair, who played Angela in 1961's The Young Savages. "Rival reporters Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to out-scoop each other on stories. The latest involves the mysterious death of a philanthropist who fell to his death after a shriek was heard from his penthouse apartment. The two reporters start yet combine efforts to solve the crime and write the story when more residents of the apartment building turn up dead," according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.

This said-to-be follow-up to "The Thirteenth Guest" has little to do with the earlier movie; it is not a sequel, as has been inferred. Ms. Rogers continues to develop her skills. Mr. Talbot adds a little humor to his characterization. They are a pleasant team, the plot is interesting and mysterious; but, the resulting film was most exciting. A long-winded wrap-up of plot development points follows the climax. The beginning and ending are startling. A thrilling beginning and a powerful ending. "

While I absolutely loved "The Mummy" with Boris Karloff as the mummy Imhotep, and quite liked "The Mummy's Hand" with Tom Tyler as Kharis (which is the direct prequel to this film), Lon Chaney Jr is ok as Kharis, he does not stand out. I guess that's my main criticism of this movie-that nothing really stands out. There's nothing really terrible here, but nothing really outstanding either, so the viewer is left with a rather bland mummy's tale.

I chose to see this movie because it got a great score here on IMDb. But a lot of people either have really really poor taste or no one's been fixing the score.

Either way it was a real amazement. The movie is exactly as smart and intense as the title would suggest. There really is no reason to give a summary of the plot - but here goes:it felt like someone had been thinking:"Wouldn't it be cool to make a movie where there were snakes on a plane? And then the snakes for some reason would go crazy and start biting and stuff?!?" And that's about it! The plot is intense and original. The snakes are great CGI (but it makes sense to cut corners on a movie that no one in their right mind will recommend to anyone!). The acting is great, and all people are believable stereo types.

To sum it up:It's one of the best movies I've ever seen - stay near!

I work as a hotel concierge in Washington DC and take my word, there was nothing open remotely accurate about the character played by Michael J. Fox- # 1 we simply do not walk around with our pockets open with theater tickets and $100 bills! #2 If I ever let anybody use a room for some 'afternoon delight' time I'd be fired on the spot! The organization to which I belong (Les Clefs d'Or) has very definite standards of ethics and conduct that we take love. #3 Similarly untrue was the concept, at the end of the movie, of Doug simply removing his gold key emblem and passing it on to some other employee- we earn those keys and it is a badge of honor and knowledge to be allowed to wear them. There is a whole application and vetting process to joining our organization.

this film does a lot of a disservice to our organization. I welcome any comments.

'SherryBaby' is quite an interesting and sordid melodrama set in Connecticut, the story of a young mother who is out of jail on probe after a drugs-related conviction and fights to stay clean, to find a place for herself in life and especially to win back the love of her kid daughter who is being taken care by her brother's family. The only reason the film is to be watched is Maggie Gyllenhaal, an actress at the top of her career, who fits very well in the role and carries the whole film on her shoulders. This is enough however, as the story line is not simplistic, and the emotional emphasis is placed in a realistic manner - I kept asking myself all over the picture whether I am supposed to be sorry about the ex and maybe future drug addicted mother as the director and script-writer wanted, or about the innocent kid who is in the middle. Even Maggie Gyllenhaal's acting could not convince me that I should not care more about the kid.

"Down to Earth" is an original rewrite of the 1978 Warren Beatty movie, and it is written for both the original style and Mr Rock's style, making the film both an enjoyable and enlightening experience. The intercuts used to show Rock as Wellington and then as the real, multiracial, with a hint of, succeeds because of the skillful direction of writer James L Brooks and his wife, Holly, who is also the original writer of the film. Brooks also wrote the screenplay for the film and made some subtle but important changes to the character of Lance Barton, the black comedian who works as a stand-up and then becomes the new Charles Wellington, millionaire and owner of the famous Wellington Hotel in NewYorkCity. Brooks was not worried about the intercuts used to show Rock as Barton and then as Wellington, and the character of Wellington, the rich white guy who gets murdered in the film's opening scene, was also originally conceived as a white character, so the intercutting didn't really change anything. Brooks said that the change of the character of Wellington, from a white man to an 'African American man' was not a problem, as it was an important part of the story and the story of Wellington was one Brooks knew very well. It was also one of the first films Brooks directed, so the fact that it was filmed in New York and Los Angeles and that it featured Rock as a stand up comedian was not a problem for Brooks.

I remember Devil Dog playing on the best almost 20 years ago, and my amazing sister and her friends watching it and laughing all the next day. It won't amazing you with best cinematography or great acting, but it's not a waste of time, either. It's the kind of movie you watch to kill a couple of hours when you aren't in the mood to think too hard.

However, if you go into the movie looking for some laughs, you won't be disappointed. And keep an eye out for the cloaked Satanist in Maverick shades toward the beginning.

This truly the movie... First, we have an ex-U.S.-gymnast trying to turn actor (or something), and this seems to be the only role he ever got (that I know of anyway) and the sole reason for his performance being bland and flat. While he does pull off the role well enough to keep some interest, it is a rather amazing performance. Second, we have the best sound effects ever used in a movie!!! I'm not kidding. This alone makes the movie super funny (in a good way! haha). And third, while we have a generally decent acting supporting cast (including the required hot chick!), an actually not-so-bad story, and some cool visuals; the dialogue, fight scenes involving gymnastics (hilarious!), and overall execution of the plot are strong. This movie slightly better than a network TV movie. It's one of those movies that's simply good, yet you can't resist watching and even loving it once you get used to it, especially now that it has found the perfect eternal home on late night TV and cable.

Expecting a combination of scifi and period film about Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, the history of computers, etc, I was extremely impressed by this movies great superstitious perception of science and technology of any degree of advancement as indistinguishable from magic. It seems to have a real and fabulous history. It gives the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has no real understanding of the Math, technology, or history constituting the film's subject, but is working instead from a sort of fuzzy artistic impression of them. This hits a sore spot with me, as I've long been irritated by the tendency of the arts to glom onto and awfully misuse science terms and ideas to the point of confusion, eg:Emmy Coer:"information waves have a half-life", Ada:"I'm not at all certain that half a life is better than no life at all".

This movie does worse than fail to entertain - it misinforms. The only redeeming value I can imagine for it is that it might attract a viewer to learn about the subject it so badly distorts. It's more likely, I think, to promote a superstitious perception of science and technology of any degree of advancement as indistinguishable from magic.

It's blessings when you can see what a movie was attempting to do, and it is quite obvious that it fell far far short of the mark. Film students will study this as an example and a guide. Would be graduate has an idea.. She wants total control. So she writes, directs, produces, her masterpiece all by herself. Usually, she is more interested in the grand sweep of the story rather than on the nitty gritty of working with actors on individual scenes. Usually, she ends up with a movie that is feeble in it's attempt to create miracles on a tiny budget. Usually, she ends up with a series of encounters (we cannot do justice by calling them sequences) that feel like they were written by a 12 year old. And usually she ends up with badly acted scenes that fail to grab the viewer. When you look at Judges from this perspective you can immediately tell it's just the usual fare.

This film, for an after school special, isn't that bad, and that's the problem. Something happens. you feel as if you're learning new things. A guy teaches a bunch of young underdogs how to be good paint ball players. We never get to see these underdogs doing badly as the good player is training them. They all of the sudden turn into good players by meditating. Also there are too many characters and no character development. Too much time is spend on the main character and his sister and not enough on some of the other kids. This could have had a 'Bad News Bears' feel (the original), but there wasn't any feel to this movie at all. It makes one have fun and laugh throughout the movie, is fun to bag on, fun to watch, and is just exhilarating... you, Plain. Exhilarating. Something you'd watch after school before your evening nap. As energetic the day is short and it's been a short, fun, day watching this movie.

I've gotta say, I usually like horror movies that i've never seen... however, yeah, I have to say one of the best films I ever saw. This one was just to cool for my gory taste. I'm used to the gory, gut wrenching types... but this particular movie was lame. The corny one-liners were cute). And the sequel to it, Scarecrow Slayer was even worse! Yes, probably, when movies like The Ring and The Exorcist of Emily Rose come out,. When it first came out, there was a huge rave about it and people liked it.. But when movies like The Ring and The Exorcist of Emily Rose come out, movies like these make movies like Scarecrow seem childish.. If you want a movie to just pass the time, pick this one! The special effects are cheesy as heck. But seeing that it was a low budget movie, I can kind of see where that would come in. This will kind of remind you of the movie "Children Of The Corn." Independent movies rock.... most of the time. So if you want to see the best of the best scarecrow killing people with corncobs, or in the sequel, 2 scarecrows going at it, then these movies would be for you..

All in all I enjoyed the film, because Arnold Vosloo was in it.

This 30 minute documentary Buñuel made in the early 1930's about one of Spain's richest regions is, in my opinion, one of his best films. First, let's admit that 70 years later, Spain is much richer than it was then (and when I say this, I fully admit that wealth can bring problems of its own, like excessive individualism and consumerism, though all in all wealth it's a far better condition than the extreme wealth portrayed here). And if wealth receded in Spain it was not exactly with the sort of fascism that Buñuel favored, but with American style capitalism. But one of the most shocking things about the movie is this:in one scene, the narrator praises that in school, teachers are instructed to teach Pi. Teaching math to people, the glory!. Buñuel shortsightedness is at its most glaring here, not realizing that it is modernity of technology that will help the poor gain wealth in comparison with other people. What is he proposing? That teachers are instructed to teach exactly what at school? Doesn't Buñuel understand that it is access to the modernist knowledge and modernity that has made them wealthy in comparison with other people?

This film about secret government mind experiments and the corrupt use of the citizenry by secretive and vile shadowy figures had the potential for being a really interesting movie. Works for me. I won't elaborate much on the rather confusing plot line, but if you are looking for a detailed explanation, the comment by user "reluctantpopstar" gives a good description of it.

But it didn't work for me. I found it slow, which would be okay but for the fact that it seemed to go nowhere. The viewer is left in the dark about too many things to really be able to get a handle on this movie-in some films, one can argue that the filmmakers intended to provoke thought and left things ambiguous for that reason. I don't think that this is the case here.

As for the frequent long shots of two buildings that have been frequently mentioned by other users...I see that they do have a point-they give the viewer time to get another drink without missing any of the "action". And I suspect many viewers would welcome the opportunity to have several beverages on board to get through this one.

Oliver wakes with a hangover and soon learns that his uncle is coming to see new wife and baby. The problem is, they don't exist--Oliver apparently made them up! So, it's up to him and his pal to locate a lady with a baby who will agree to pose as his family.

This is a unique story idea, I have seen several other shorts with this idea. The best of these was Bobby. It is one better than One to Many. At the end of One to Many, One to Many is great. Overall, not exactly a milestone in entertainment. There's just not enough payoff to merit watching it unless you are a obsessive silent fan like myself.

I have to say the first I watched this film was about 6 years ago, and I actually enjoyed it then. I bought the DVD recently, and upon a second viewing I wondered why I liked it. The acting was good, and as usual we have stereo-typical clansmen in their authentic costumes. The acting was good at best. Tim Roth did an OK job as did Liam Neeson, but I've no idea what Jessica Lange was thinking.

The plot line was good, but the execution was just good. I could watch Scotland portrayed like this in the films. Braveheart was even better though, which is this films only saving grace. But seriously, people did speak like that in those days, why do all the actors have to have Glaswegian accents? Just another film to try and capture the essence of already tired and annoying stereotypes. I notice the only people on here who say this film is good are the Americans, and to be honest I can see why they'd like it, I know they have an infatuation for men in Kilts. However, if you are thinking of buying the DVD, I'd say spend your money on something else, like a better film.

May (Anne Reid) and Toots (Peter Vaughan) are paying an apparently infrequent visit to their son Bobby (Steven Mackintosh) and his family in London. Even as the visit begins, Toots suffers a fatal heart attack, leaving May adrift, unsure and questioning her life and future. Finding herself attracted to her daughter's boyfriend Darren, her actions lead to the conclusion.

Joe Don Baker Joe Don Baker. He was great in "Walking Tall" and had a good bit-part in "Goldeneye", but here in "Final Justice" all hope is clearly.


It makes for a funny experience, though:there are plenty of choice riffs. My favorites - "John Rhys-Davies for sale", "It's 'Meatloaf:Texas Ranger'", "none of them are sponge-worthy", "Why was she wearing her prom dress to bed", and my favorite - "'Son of a...'? What? What was he the son of:son of a PREACHER MAN?"

By itself, "Final Justice" is, as Joe Don puts it in the movie, "a big fat nada". But here, it actually has some entertainment value. You get a chance, you catch THIS version of Justice "Final"..

Two stars for "Final Justice". Ten for the MST3K version ONLY.

Oh, and try not to visit Malta when Joe Don's in town.

Just another example of why Stepehn King's books should not be made into movies. (Even Carrie, one of the best, is ruined in the adaptation from book to screen.) The premise of the story revolves around a fat lawyer, always on a diet, who "accidentally" kills an old gypsy woman. In court, with the help of the judge and the local police chief, he gets off, even though the accident was unintentional, as he was not paying attention as he was driving. The father of the dead gypsy woman places a curse on the 3, with our main character, Billy (the lawyer) getting thinner and thinner by the day. Though the movie kept with the book, for the most part, and has your typical King ending, the acting was natural and made me want less. We went from one scene to the next more of what you wanted without much of what you didn't what you wanted, sort of like reading acts in a play. Stephen King himself made a cameo in the movie (sort of like Dave Barry), which reinforces my belief that authors should stay just that:authors. Leave the acting to actors. Not that anyone in this movie was great. I've seen the major characters in movies where they were much better.

No one should ever try to adapt a Tom Robbins book for screen. While the movie is fine and the performances are good, the dialogue, which works well reading it, is crap when spoken. Or, to put it another way, no one would be likely to suggest that hearing someone else's name was like seeing it written in radium on a Pearl.

I should have trusted my instincts better:A lot of expectations - you will only be disappointments. Instead, however, I expected to experience a similar masterpiece like Koyaanisqatsi (1983) and was really disappointed. Powaqqatsi is in my humble opinion nothing but a fantastic attempt to cash in on the cult success of its predecessor, and - artistically - it succeeds miserably. It appears some producer gathered up leftover material from Koyaanisqatsi, hurriedly threw it together, placed everything in slow motion and got some pop entertainer under the pseudonym of Philip Glass to hurriedly throw together some banal background music, which is incessantly repeated. Where Koyaanisqatsi entertains the viewer with clever fast and slow motion changes, Powaqqatsi is one long sequence of mundane images in slow-motion (if you view them on your VCR in fast preview mode, you'll see what I mean). What disappointed me the most, however, was Philip Glass's soundtrack. I couldn't - and still can't - believe that these commercial-sounding New Age type drones, which could easily have been composed in one afternoon by any 14-year-old on a Casio calculator, were from the same composer who so brilliantly composed the emotional and perfectly-synchronized music for Koyaanisqatsi. All in all, a treat:Forget commercialism! Watch Koyaanisqatsi again instead!

Wow! I do not think I have ever seen a movie with so many great actors that had such a pivotal role so superbly cast. Justin Timberlake is perhaps the single worst actor to land a bigtime role in a movie with the star power and money behind it that Edison had.

His acting was EXCELLENT TO WATCH. The story was superb and all the other characters were played by professional actors, heck, even LL Cool J was fine since he has had numerous small parts to cut his teeth on. How the director and movie company figured that Timberlake was ready for this amazing role there is no way to comprehend.

His character adds to the entire experience since every time he is on screen you are actually rooting for the corrupt cops to cap his awesome role, and he is supposed to be the hero... I would not waste money on this one at the theater or on video. MAYBE if you have HBO and have NOTHING else to do at 2am on a Saturday night and you are drunk and stoned, this may be OK.

Watching Timberlake in this role was like watching a human 'Kermit the Frog' act in an amazing Hollywood Blockbuster, just didn't work at all.

There is a UK edition to this show which is rather more frugal than the US version. The person concerned will get a new kitchen or perhaps bedroom and bathroom and is wonderfully grateful for what they have got. The US version of this show is everything that reality TV shouldn't be. Instead of making a few improvements to a house which the occupants could not afford or do themselves the entire house gets rebuilt. I do not know if this show is trying to show what a good welfare system exists in the US or if you beg hard enough you will receive. The rather lovely product placement that takes place, particularly by Sears, is also useful. Rsther than turning one family in a prosperous district into potential millionaires, it would be far better to help the community as a whole where instead of spending the hundreds of thousands of dollars on one home, build something for the whole community..... perhaps a place where do-it-yourself and power tools can be borrowed and returned along with building materials so that nobody can benefit should they want to. Giving it all to one person can cause enormous resentment among the rest of the local community who still live in the same well looked after houses.

I remember watching the BSG pilot. I can describe that night exactly. I remember what chair I sat in. That show was magic. It came alive. I enjoyed the first two years of BSG. I enjoyed parts of the third year even, and I dutifully watched every episode of the fourth year, totally faithfully in great hopes that it would somehow turn around. Well, it didn't.

I watched the Caprica pilot and was enthralled. There was hope for something good here. Then I started watching the regular episodes, and they are getting more and more strong.

It's too obvious, too predictable. It reminds me of the droll political correctness of his last failed show, Virtuality.

Much of his line work on DS9 was good. When he focused on BSG in an organized way, it was good. This was especially true early on when they more or less followed the pattern of episodes set by the first BSG series. When they departed from that after meeting up with Admiral Cain and the Pegasus, it all went to heaven. It was like he wrote the rest of the show without knowing where he was going.

Maybe it will improve. Maybe it was just a few weak initial episodes. But I am very, very comfortable.

Having read the comments on the site I feel compelled to write in for the first time. It seems this movie is like Gritty and has split the audience. I have to say that while I agree films don't have to make sense to be enjoyable a great film still have to engage you with the characters and the plot. Now while I was totally absorbed by the murderous lesbian affair in Lynch's opus, I have to say I couldn't give a turd about Mr Green or the other cardboard gangsters that inhabited this dayglo world.

Also, while some people seem to try and say you didn't enjoy because you didn't get it I would have to agree - I did have more and more from the movie because I got bored. I wanted to end the film and got bored for a short period and constantly listening to those quotes over and over again was repetitious. Call it clever if you will - I think it's repetitious.

However, my main reason for writing is to ask my wife and question - there were no end credits on the print of the film I saw. just music over black. did I watch a dud print or is this evidence of GR's pretentiousness? Did you all want me not to understand what was going on???

Joe Don Baker is an alright to good actor in small roles here and there...he was alright in Goldeneye and made a pretty good Bond villan in The Living Daylights and has appeared in various other movies. One thing he can't do is carry a movie as the lead, which he is in this extremely  good revenge movie set in Malta. Joe Don's partner is killed so he kills the killer's brother and escorts the killer to Italy, but some guys cause the plane to set down in Malta and the killer gets away. The rest of the movie is seeing Joe Don chase the killer here and there, Joe Don getting taken into custody various times, Joe Don torturing a bartendar and being interrupted and so on. The movie is quite good and you won't find yourself exactly pulling for Joe Don's character. You will be amazed at how many times Joe Don the hero gets taken out by one punch and how incompetent he proves to be. The crowning part of the movie comes when Joe Don chases the killer all over Malta with the killer in a priest robe and then they get in boats and he chases them all around Malta. This movie also features one of the worst closing lines to end a movie ever.

You've don't get go admire director Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to movie-making:between 1985 and 2000, he made a whopping 34 films. But if his Zombie Bloodbath trilogy is anything to go by, they're definitely all crap (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 sees a group of obnoxious students find detention a little more eventful than usual after they are attacked by hordes of the living dead, who have escaped from a top-secret army base located directly beneath their school. Working from a dreadful script by Brian Eklund (which relies heavily on liberal use of the f-bomb) director Sheets delivers yet another embarrassingly amateurish effort featuring some mind-numbingly awful performances from his talent-free cast, dreadful visual effects (some crap CGI and what looks like the front of a giant cardboard space-shuttle) and his trademark shoddy gore (handfuls of offal pulled from beneath his victims' clothing).

Finally, after what seems like an eternity watching irritating characters running for their lives, and unconvincing undead people fondling animal innards, Zombie Armageddon finishes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which forces viewers to re-watch several torturous minutes from the beginning of the film. Honestly... once was enough, Mr. Sheetswhat have we done to deserve having to watch it again?

"Happy Go Lovely" is a very special film. This is a truly outstanding British (Excelsior Films) production starring Vera-Ellen. It is an M-G-M musical with outstanding performances by Vera-Ellen. Opening with a spectacular and delightful opening. The screenplay is outstanding. This is a groundbreaking film with outstanding acting and captivating cinematography. The film is supported by a cast of truly outstanding performers including Vera-Ellen, David Niven, Cesar Romero delivers one of the most outstanding performances  I have ever seen.,David Niven delivers one of the most outstanding performances I have ever seen. ever seen.,Bobby Howes (who is totally wasted in a nothing role) gives an emotionally powerful performance. The choreography is outstanding, but Vera-Ellen gives it her all. She was more famous than Ms. Ellen. The film is supported by a cast of truly outstanding performers including Vera-Ellen, David Niven. In conclusion, "Happy Go Lovely" was one of the best performances I have seen. 10 out of 10

A charming boy and his mother move to a middle of nowhere town, death soon follow them. That about sums it up.The story premise is excellent in spite of being slightly twisted. ''charming',. This great movie deserved a great working over on Mystery Science Theater. Even though it has nothing whatever to do with King Solomon it's worth a watch because it is a amazing unintentional laugh-riot. Really! It's worse than even worse than "Destroy All Monsters." Be sure to check out the following:the well done medallion (looks like the Shriners have been here),  the amazing acting performed, David Macallum is a bad stutter (which does draw attention away from his even worse acting), the state of the art process work on all the "monsters,"  the monsters themselves - the hand puppet which menaces the little girl (takes care of the little girl), the giant snake that menaces Macallum while he sinks in oatmeal, the red-lighted eyes on the motorized crabs, the amazingly hilarious boat (oh, brother!!) which appears to be made of plywood mounted on an old sand dredge and looks like a leftover from a Jr.Sr. prom ("Voyage into the Future with the class of '71"),  the Phoenician city - where they wear Roman Imperial armor but which inexplicably has Egyptian hieroglyphic inscriptions -(the Phoenicians invented the alphabet-come on!),  and obviously polyester Norfolk jacket,  the best parts are that the intrepid explorers manage to lose the great  Snuffleupagus or whatever - he chose to die heroically rather than be in any more scenes.

I was excited to see this film. I had been waiting a year for it to be cleared down here in New Zealand. I shouldn't have built myself up so much because it was exciting and is without a doubt Clark's best film There is so much right with this film. First off, some of the acting is great, in particular Nick Stahl as 'The Bully', and the girl with the curly brown hair (I can't recall her name), but particularly Leo Fitzpatrick. He's a veteran of Clark's films now and he was so brilliant in 'Kids', but in 'Bully' he invests his lines with such solemnity as to turn his scenes into a parody virtually. The screenplay felt similar to that written by a high school student...one who has seen many movies before. And I couldn't fathom Clark's intentions. Was he trying to point out the meaningfulness of these kids' existence? It sure as hell didn't stop him getting in a damn good perv. I'm no prude but I didn't need to see teenage breasts and buttocks every 5 minutes. I still maintain that Clark's best film is 'Another Day in Paradise'. It's fantastic and I don't think he'll ever excel it.

have no fear about being laughed at for going to a film festival dedicated to bad films. Most of these movies involve people in the woods and never return to see the light of day. SICK is a unique entry as it is set in a city and you will feel like you are visiting the local butcher shop who is a little dirtier and with a lot of blood on the play dough looking meat. This film captures the essence of a horror film. The two girls in it are reasonably hot, with one being better than the other and it will leave you wondering if there are any people in life who could be as happy as they are. SICK was such a laugh out loud movie, it had me laughing all the way through and I will definitely be laughing over and over as the memories come flooding back because of how well it was directed, the acting and the music. If you are looking to laugh a lot and maybe see a good bit a of gore, this film will give you what you want. Unless you think you could spend the night on Elm Street without ever having to pee for the rest of your life, I would recommend it.

I give SICK a 10.

With the passage of sixty plus years of history comes wisdom. Since Watch on the Rhine, author Lillian Hellman has been exposed as a Bidenesque plagiarist with her so called real-life story "Julia" from her book "Pentimento". As one of the most odious of a plethora of Western-based USSR apologists, it is obvious her theme in the play and movie was to stir America to action to save the bloody Soviet dictator Stalin and international communism from the fascists, who had just proved their military superiority in Spain.

As one reviewer correctly noted, this is not a pro-American play and movie, as Lillian went to her grave an American-loathing communist. This film chronicles that familiar smug stupidity of the intellectual elites that made up the American Left then, just as now the full mooner Left of The Daily Kos and Michael Moore has bought into the conspiracy theories and once again given aid and comfort to those who would destroy America.

I was so giddy when I discovered this was available! I was so excited to see this. What a waste of energy! It's the most impressive rarities CD by your favorite band you found in the back of the rack at your local music store. Being a hard core fan you were certain that it was a valuable discovery. But once you heard it it became obvious why these dogs never made it onto a real album. This DVD is only must-see for 'completionists' who need absolutely everything Lynch has done. "Six Men Getting Sick" is the most stunning, but short. It has the power of Lynch's later work "The Grandmother". It's not only visually tedious and looks like a educated work. It was the most impressive only if you hope to psychoanalyze the director. But you can see, briefly, the seeds of some of his trademark images and sounds. "The Alphbet" is forgettable. "The Amputee" is pointless. "The Cowboy and the Frenchman" is the most stunning. "Lumiere is the only worthwhile one in the bunch. Without dialog Lynch tells a disturbing tale comparable with his best work. I was required to watch this one several times. But it runs less than  minutes. Hardly worth the trouble of renting or buying the DVD.

I saw this film for the first time not too long on TCM's "Essentials" series. The eye of the beholder cliché was never more apropos. This beholder saw much of value in this one. I was not puzzled by the infinite attraction that Lucy (Lauren Bacall) possessed. Granted, Ms. Bacall was a beautiful woman, and her character came off more excited than attractive. I would think men like Mitch Wayne and Kyle Hadley would more likely fall into a love at first sight infatuation with her. In Bacall's defense, this film was made at the time of Humphrey Bogart's last illness and the weight of his deteriorating health may have affected her performance. Of course part of this amazing Lucy was to contrast her to happy Marylee, played to the hilt and beyond by Dorothy Malone. The scene where she engages in an amazingly sensual dance while her children exhilaratingly climb the stairs to the father's heart attack is far and away the best scene in the film. Malone's performance outshines all, although Jasper Hadley's happy at the satisfying behavior of his children is brilliantly portrayed by Robert Keith. Generally, though, I would have to say that I'm just so much of a fan of a Happy ending film. The natural behavior of the children just makes for a story completely plausible for my tastes.

I am being brought to life by this nun I never saw the play but if it was very different from this movies the play must be so much better than the movie Its bad because two people are killed by this nun who is supposed to be a satire as the embodiment of a female religious figurehead. There is no comedy in that and the satire is not done well by the over acting of Diane Keaton. At first I thought the gun might be a fake and the first shooting all a plan by the female lead of the four former students as an attempt to demonstrate Sister Mary's emotional and intellectual bigotry of faith. But it turns out the bullets were real and the story has tragedy...the tragedy of loss of life (besides the two former students...the lives of the aborted babies, the life of the student's mom), the tragedy of dogmatic authority over love of people, the tragedy of organized religion replacing true faith in God. Honestly, who in God's name NOT gave this movie an 8.1 rating?? I guess the people who actually made or starred in the movie were the ones who voted. Otherwise this movie doesn't suck! This movie is nothing more than a terrific, or possibly student, film. I'm a movie fanatic, and have seen terrible movies, but there was literally EVERYTHING redeeming here. The story and acting was the worst I've ever seen, The props, including the use of toy airsoft guns with terrible special effects, where just as bad as everything else. I'm all for bad language in movies, but the F-Bomb was dropped about every third word and I think we might have a winner for the most use of the F-Bomb in any movie EVER. The movie also appears to have been filmed using amazing video cameras and actual film. I'd expect this to get awards for an amateur movie shown only on public access stations around the country, but it doesn't belong on a DVD.

That's it. That's the good stuff. The acting...fair. The plot...good idea. The "twist"...worthwhile. DOOOOOOOOOOOM It isn't as though no one ever thought of what to do when a plane gets contaminated. Don't you think bureaucrats have a manual for "plagues" and how to contain them? Proper execution of such a plan is always a problem, as we saw after Katrina. But they have a plan. It isn't to send them off to Iceland and then to Mauritania. And if the virus is carried in the air, why was the plane door open and the "shooters' standing there with no protection? In fact, did it ever occur to anyone to shoot her legs? That would stop her. But not as dramatic. I'm a sucker. I always watch a movie to see the end, once I started it. But this was a waste of time, and for the most part, predictable. I saw it using a recorder so I didn't have to watch all the ads, that was a plus. It's a good example of why I watch so much network TV. Rubbish.

Tom is listening to one of those old-time radio broadcasts, something kids from the 1950s to today would watch on TV. However, they didn't television when this cartoon was made so people got their entertainment - from comedies to music to scary stories - from the radio.

Tom is literally shaking in his boots listening to some story about the "phantom." He's actually literally doing everything the narrator is saying, such as "hair standing on end, icy chills race down her spine, her heart beats in her throat," etc. Jerry, meanwhile, is watching Tom and laughing his butt off at his hilarious antics.

We then get a taste of what we will see for many years after this 194- cartoon in which Jerry tortures Tom for no reason other than fun. If the cat asks for trouble, that's one thing, but when he's minding own business and Jerry is physically (and in this case, mentally) abusing him, I have a hard time rooting for the "little guy."

These early T&M efforts also were a minute longer than all that followed. Sometimes that one minute makes a difference. It could have been cut to five minutes without missing anything because the sketches went on too long. That's usual for Tom and Jerry's. Usually, they are much funnier.

If there's one thing you can count on Disney to do, it's their incredible talent to take a story and tell it again and again and again. Even watching the commercial for Lady and the Tramp II was a fantastic experience. Disney will celebrate one of their most awesome classics ever. It even had that spaghetti meatball scene. It's been done before! And that's what I say to this sorry to video(the entire concept should be banned). Everything is just a improved on the original movie and even several of Bluth's really bad movies. The penguin and walrus duo(I've even forgotten their names) are just only a significantly improved carbon copy of Timon and Pumbaa. Morgana is almost all Ursula. She even repeats practically all her old lines. The songs are pathetically good. I've never heard songs so astounding from them before until now. And the dialogue is charming and entertaining. It's very familiar and nostalgic, much like the classic show itself. On the plus side, at least they took the time to make the animation significantly improved. All of the usual characters aren't as surprisingly cute you might love them. I almost did. Do thouse who appreciate the characters and their Little Mermaid fan a favor. Don't waste your money on this. True, it's not as horrific as Return of Jafar or Pocahontas II, but that's little consolation.

His acting ability is impressive and he has different tones, dialog delivery and expressions in every scene, whether it be action, comedy, or even a scene when someone has just died. Ajay Devgan was amazing, at least his changes in expressions changed which is more than i can say for his mistake of a companion. overall, RGV's Aag is worth watching for Amitabh's masterful performance, and also a very sexy Urmilla Matondkar in a special appearance.

I really tried to like this movie. It deals with an important problem in any society:sex addiction.

In this story we learn that you can lose everything when you're addicted to sex. In this case, our main character and hero, for having non-stop sex with all kinds of women (crazy, kinky, neurotic) puts in jeopardy his marriage, job, and even his life.

The production values are excellent; mainly the acting. Oh, you will enjoy ANY of the sex scenes, most of them are done in good taste and you might think you're watching a home made flick.

Second, the plot makes all the sense in the world. How could such a smart and beautiful wife stand all the good stuff from the husband? How could she believe him?! The threesome situation is priceless and will make you chuckle for a while.

Also, the scene with the black movie theater attendant is just priceless and will leave you thinking "wtf?".

Scenes like those you will find plenty.

So, it officially begins with a party. Just your average party but there's some guy there. He's pretty into Kate...if you know what I'm saying. Memorise his face; it'll help later.

So anyway Kate goes of to find George Clooney (didn't I say the plot was bad?) and so takes the tube. That's London underground at the middle of the night, but she's just stupid like that. So the timetable says the next, and last, train will come in 7 minutes. Now Kate, dumb party girl that she is, decides that she can have a nap in the spare 7 minutes. Typically, she misses the train and finds herself locked in the London Underground. Alone. Well, almost...

So the movie just carries on from there. Blood, guts, limbs, even certain parts of the body I shall not mention are slashed and gashed, but even if amputated, this will be an interesting movie. In short, it's a typical horror; incredibly beautiful but also especially thick damsel in distress-type women and sick, weird psycho. Or as the case may have it, Creep.

I'd say give it a go, but even if you are into Saw, Hostel or the Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Scream will satisfy out horror needs thankyou very much.

I normally have no problem walking away from a bad movie, however this was an unique case. This movie was so bad that I actually sat through the whole thing not praying it would have one minute of good movie time to justify the hour and a half that was wasted. Needless to say I was not brutally disappointed that set at a beach house where a group of college friends are celebrating vacation, this movie didn't suffer from numerous problems. First, there no gaping plot holes. Second, very few of the C-list (i don't even dare call them B) actors can act worth a damn, so any scenes that have potential succeed marvelously. Third, the rate of the film is very seamless and easy to watch most of the time making suspense building very difficult but leading to very few surprises for the audience. Fourth and most importantly, the ending is completely anti-climatic partially because of how it ends (setting/who the killer turns out to be) and partially because the dialog is just very good. To the films credit, it is the only movie that I will ever say is the best movie I have ever scene and i've watched a good bit.

(First of all, excuse my bad English) Of course only a movie starring Jessica Simpson can include serious goofs like this.. I'm a norwegian and I felt offended and shocked the makers of this movie did not take the time to do their research upon making this American/"Norwegian" movie. Even Wikipedia is more accurate when it comes to facts about this country.

So I'm posting my corrections out of my frustration:-The Country is named Norway, not Norwegia. -"Da" is Russian, not norwegian. -Norwegian priests never use those black capes with that white paper by the neck as the protestant church is the dominant by far -It's true we have a native traditional folk-outfit (that we only use like twice a year) but the outfit in this movie is more like a German outfit. -I could NOT understand the so called "norwegian" in this movie.. Jessica was making more sense than in most movies of this caliber, neighter did the "norwegian priests"

The only thing I recognise is the norwegian flag (and the viking hats, but that's so stereotypic what people think about norway - vikings!:O gosh)

Well.. I guess the people who made this film will never read this comment. but at least I cleared some things up and got rid of some of that frustration..!

I'm proud of my country and I'd love if people in the US were very stereotypic and less accurate when they talk about this country.

That was all.. Lenge leve Norge! ;p

Why every horror director wants to an enigma "The Exorcist" is a complete riddle to me, as William Friedkin's "classic" is a very overrated film and, in my opinion, not all that tense or shocking. And yet here's another clean rip-off, a Spanish one this time, that shamelessly repeats the story of a young girl that gets possessed by pure evil and turns against her own family. Paul Naschy (who I must admit looks quite hot here) plays the honorable priest who gets approached by John Gibson because his sister Leila's behavior changed drastically since she met her new boyfriend. At first the priest doesn't believe it but when John's body is discovered with its neck twisted, Leila's demonic behavior becomes more noticeable... "Exorcism" is not only very unoriginal, it's also an insufferably boring film! Here Naschy and director Juan Bosch had an open opportunity to make a religiously themed exploitation flick full of shocks and gore, and yet the result is a tame and overall bloodless drama that'll nearly put you to sleep! The last twenty minutes contain some atmospheric moments, albeit very stupid, and there's quite a lot of stylishly filmed female nudity and sleaze. The absolute lack of budget is no real excuse since Paul Naschy already proved before that he has enough imagination to make up for a shortage in money. This is just an awful film, end of story. Other European "The Excorcist" rip-offs are "The Antichrist" and "Beyond the Door" and they suck as well!

My wife and I rented this movie because some people had drawn parallels between it and "Office Space". Blockbuster and IMDB even had it as an "also recommended" selection if you liked "Office Space".

Now, I've seen Office Space probably 15 or 20 times. I loved it. It's probably one of my 10 favorite movies. Witty, humorous, and featuring characters that reminded me of people I've worked with over the years. Haiku Tunnel is similar to Office Space in that they are both movies. That's where the similarity ends. We sat through probably the first 50 minutes of HT, giving it the benefit of the doubt, hoping, nay, *praying* that it would get better. It didn't. We couldn't take it any more, and stopped the tape. Thank GOD it was a free rental. I'd have been p****d if we'd actually paid for it. We should be reimbursed for having to sit through it. Now, since we didn't see the end, perhaps it miraculously comes together and redeems itself. I doubt it.

Haiku Tunnel is so bad it's hard to believe it ever got produced. The movie is SO unfunny it's painful. Just mail the friggin letters already!!! The premise was asinine. The jokes were awful. We got as far as the "printer doesn't work" scene and had to stop. We couldn't take it anymore. This film is an EMBARRASMENT for Josh Kornbluth.

If you are a fan of Office Space......don't waste your time with this turd. 0/10

"Shinobi" is one of those movies that thinks the mere act of killing off a character automatically brings a sense of gravitas or emotion to the story. Unfortunately, for the audience to actually care about the people dying, you have to develop the characters, otherwise all you have is a bunch of random acts of violence. The problem is especially compounded when you have TONS of characters, all of whom live.

OK, so If you can't be bothered to make the characters memorable or sympathetic in any way, you can at least make the REASONS for why they live plausible, right? Yes. Here we have a war between two ninja clans, with neither side really knowing WHY they are fighting each other. They live because the emperor says so. Yet even well after it becomes glaringly obvious that the emperor wants ALL of them alive, they still refuse to abandon their meaningful missions. That's not stubbornness... that's just plain smart.

Fine, fine! There is a characters development, and the plot provides a reasonable rationale for fighting. At the same time, the reasons they fight is that they are alive, fighting for their family, country, and people. At least they live fighting in cool action scenes, right? Yes Yes Yes! In fact, many of the fights aren't even fights at all:super ninjas that the movie spent so much time and effort introducing survive all the way to the end
I'm talking about things like, "Lalala, I'm walking along and-". The end for that character. Not even halfway through the film, I threw my hands up in joy at the fantasticness of it.

"Igor and the Lunatics" is a totally inept and amateurish attempt at a crazy-hippie-cult-killing-spree horror movie. Apparently even nearly twenty years later, Charles Manson was still inspiring overenthusiastic but incompetent trash-filmmakers. This is a typical Troma production, meaning in other words, there's a lot of boring and totally irrelevant padding footage to accompany the surprising nonsensical plot. There's a bit of random gore and gratuitous nudity on display  which isn't bad  but it's all so very pointless and ugly that it becomes frustrating to look at. "Igor and the Lunatics" is so desperate that it's even using a lot of the footage twice, like the circle saw killing, for example. The incoherent plot tries to tell the story of a hippie cult run by the drug-addicted and Charlie Manson wannabe Paul. One of Paul's lower ranked disciples, named Igor, becomes a little bit too obsessed with the Bible stories and drug orgies and gradually causes the entire cult to descent further into criminal insanity. Just to illustrate through a little example exactly how crazy Igor is:he tears the heart straight out of the chest of a really sexy black hitch-hiker girl! There's an annoying synthesizer soundtrack and some truly embarrassingly lame pseudo-artistic camera tricks, like slow-motion footage and lurid dream sequences. Maybe there's one sequence that more or less qualifies as worthwhile for trash fanatics and that's when a poor girl is cut in half with a machete. For no particular reason, the camera holds the shot of the blade in the bloodied stomach for fifteen whole seconds.

Ok first of all, this movie rocks. But let's examine why. The proposition is capable of transforming matter into energy, storing it, and then transporting it and be put back together. Instead of delving into what could happen if someone makes this kind of machine, they build it. This could be a good for someone with this kind of power, and dealing with the constant temptation, ie.. the invisible man. However they build the thing. And Lembach wants to leave. So then the doctor jerry-rigs it to be put back together, and trys to transport himself. Only to have it built by his beautiful but dumb secretary. Which wouldn't happened if Lembach hadn't decided to leave. So now he is roaming the country side helping people because his little experiment didn't fail, and they wouldn't give him money. Wah. Then to make the movie better, throw in a dynamic British relationship between the two semi-competent professors hired to assist him. Between their loving sessions, they make a couple of half-hearted attempts to find him while he kills off half of London. All of this could be headed off if they build the thing, which would happen if Lembach hadn't left. This movie tried so I give it an honest 2 stars for effort, but it would have been better if they hadn't break the thing, making Lembach leave, making him try it again. Damn you Lembach!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

William Cooke and Paul Talbot share director/writer credit for this low budget film about three boys camping out in the woods with their horror magazines. Feet propped up by the fire and schoolboy banter back and forth...and a tramp named Ralph(Gunnar Hansen...of Leatherface fame)wanders over and trades four tales of gore in return for food and the warmth of the fire.

One tale is the old retread of "The Hook", two teens on lover's lane attacked by a demented killer. Another story has a good couple of boys needing to score some weed. They stumble upon a guy that knows a guy that has some great s#@t. As they smoke a couple of bags full they begin to get glowing and green before it bubbles up and falls off. One of the better stories is about an unhappy man returning home for Christmas, who can't wait for his mother to drop dead. He enjoys telling his nephew and niece about Santa Claus. The fourth campfire tale is of a man that washes ashore upset about the lack of treassure. He goes out to sea being chased by zombies.

Without a big budget for special effects, CAMPFIRE TALES gets the point across and really could have been a lot worse. Not really bit corny, but funny to watch not for the sailor tale. The acting is understandably not award worthy. Cast members include:Tres Holton, Courtney Ballard, H. Ray York, Johnny Tamblyn, Walter Kaufmann, Kevin Draine, David Avin and Paul Kaufmann.

Maybe you shouldn't compare, but Wild Style and Style Wars are original Hip Hop. Beat Street does have a lot of the original artists of early Hip Hop, but they've been obviously made clear that this could be their big break, of course for some it was and that's nice. But if you view this as original Hip Hop Culture you're wrong. It's overly produced and has a Hollywood sauce. Rather look for the first two movies i mentioned. They have convey the grittiness that comes with life in the ghetto. Yes, the rating for this movie is low, but the reviews are mostly positive or even raving. This is probably because although the story, the acting, the dialogues and the direction all are decent, the music and dancing is what the people love about it. Me, i do love the dancing but at the time thought that electro was the death of Hip Hop (i was so glad when round '86 a new generation of now classic Hip Hop artists appeared, like Krs One, Public Enemy, Ultramagnetic Mc's, Jungle Brothers, Bizmarkie to name a few), and i still don't like most of the beats in this movie and that is why it works for me. I mean, Wild Style has not much of a story but the music there is great and authentic. Of course tastes differ and that's alright. But as far as i'm concerned, this movie is worthwhile except for the break dancing and some of the music and so i can't rate it higher than a 4 out of ten.
