I personally liked "The Prophecy" of 1995 a lot. Christopher Walken was, as always, great, and even though the film wasn't flawless, it was a creepy and highly original Horror/Fantasy film that entertained immensely. One cannot deny that Christopher Walken is the reason this film is worth watching, but the weakest of the three "Prophecy" films. Walken is one of the greatest actors around, in my opinion, and he is once again outstanding in the role of the fallen Archangel Gabriel, whom he plays for the second time here. Once again, the war between fallen and loyal Angels is brought to earth. Gabriel returns in order to prevent the birth of a child, namely the child of the angel Danyael (Russel Wong) and the human woman Valerie (Jennifer Beals). This child could once be the determining factor of the celestial war... As I said above, Christopher Walken is once again excellent as Gabriel. Besides Gabriel, however, "The Prophecy II" includes some annoying characters are included. A great atmosphere is created in the film. Gabriel's resurrection scene in the beginning is furthermore quite impressive, and one of the coolest moments in any horror film. "The Prophecy II" is easily the best of the three "Prophecy" films. Definitely a Christopher Walken one-man-show, entertaining, and full of great moments.

I am sure you would have enjoyed this fantastic:I am in a wheelchair due to a neuromuscular disorder and like to watch the few films made about those with physical disabilities:At first I found the main character somewhat noble and captivating:His message about the disabled and the life time he spent fighting to have the disabled recognized and integrated into mainstream society's job market is great:And my problem isn't with the real person who did these things. HE was a great man:But this film is completely hypocritical and diametrically opposed to the very message it is preaching, that I found it insulting:dis genuine:Sure they were competent actors, but it seems completely dis genuin:But the CGI in this:

My dear Lord,what a movie! Let's talk about the "special effects" first. Don't get me wrong here, I am not one of those effect fanatics but I actually thought superimposition was a practice of the long gone past, mainly the 60's. So for some time I thought they might have recorded this movie a long time ago and it took them forever to cut and release it. But as far as I know they did not have cell phones in the 60's...

What I am looking for in movies is mainly a good story with a really good message. Acting is secondary, effects are secondary, I do not even mind a few little inconsistencies. However, in a movies like this bad acting, incredibility, etc. add up to make a bad movie even worse - that's what happened for me with the Celestine Prophecy.

My wife said the book was actually really good and even though I am not into all that spiritual stuff I can somehow see that it can be brought across in a believable way - the movie failed to do so.

There could be one single reason to watch this one though. If you really love cheesy movies it'll be the right one for you. If the IMDb stars were for cheesiness instead of quality I MUST have rated this movie ten stars.

By the way, three stars are for the fact that there are worse movies out there, like "Critical Mass" (look up the comments on that one - hilarious). The Celestine Prophecy is at least entertaining to a certain degree. It was a wonderful time watching it!. It felt more like a wonderful and entertaining attempt of a TV production rather than a Hollywood movie.

"Situates at the heart of the Australian" takes place at a dive diner/gas station in the middle of the Australian desert run by Tom McGregor (Paul Mercurio), a shy guy who suddenly comes to realize, we get what, at first, confusingly seems like a flashback in which he and his sister (though their relationship to each other is better understood later in the film) are speeding through the desert on his motorcycle. Afterwards, he appears as a terribly quiet, and sometimes, moody character in the presence of the arrivals. We know one thing is for sure and that is McGregor's intuition, his foresight of danger and such--his clairvoyance only slightly relevant to the story, whose bulk of which concerns three diamond thieves who's car breaks down and who rely on Tom to help them out of the spot without getting in their way. Of course, Tom falls for one of the thieves, a young woman named Charlie, and suddenly, it pits all three against each other. But not in a way that really builds the tension and suspense. In fact, the whole movie all the while seems to want to build up to something significant, but really, the movie fails. Even the ending, of which plays out like a trite campfire tale, almost just as ridiculous. It may be worth trying if you don't mind the slow pacing, but are in the mood, at least, for something a little different than the usual.

In 1454, in France, the sorcerer Alaric de Marnac (Paul Naschy) is decapitated and his mistress Mabille De Lancré (Helga Liné) is tortured to death accused of witchcraft, vampirism and lycanthropy. Before they die, they curse the next generations of their executioners. In the present days (in the 70's), Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) and Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and their friends Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) and his beloved Paula (Cristina Suriani) go to a séance session, where they evoke the spirit of Alaric de Marnac. They decide to travel to the Villas de Sade, a real estate of Hugo's family in the countryside, to seek a monastery with a hidden treasure. They find Alaric's head and the fiend possesses them, bringing Mabille back to life and executing the locals in gore sacrifices. After the death of her father, Elvira (Emma Cohen) recalls that he has the Thor's Hammer amulet hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to defeat the demoniac Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box of films with five DVDs of Paul Naschy per US$ 9.98; thanks to having no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version "Horror Rises from the Tomb" is a trash B (or C) movie that immediately made me recall Ed Wood. The ridiculous story is disclosed through awful screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, decoration, special effects and edition and with lots of naked women. The result is simply hilarious and I can guarantee that Ed Wood's style is back. My vote is three.

"National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is absolutely the best movie ever made, surpassing even the excellent "Plan 9 from Outer Space." The Lampoon film unreels in three separate vignettes, each featuring different performers. The only common thread is the total lack of any redeeming characteristics.

Anyone who has a remote interest in science fiction should start at the basics. Everyone says STAR WARS and STAR TREK are the best science fiction films to begin at, which is fine but the truth is THE TERMINATOR and this movie, SOYLENT GREEN, are far better choices than those series. SOYLENT is probably science fiction's best kept secret. It remains one of the biggest, yet most forgotten films but the impact of its setting is becoming more a reality with each passing day. Charlton Heston overdramatizes his role, yet it works. Edward G. Robinson, in his final role, makes the most out of it in SOYLENT GREEN more than anyone else and his final scenes are touching.

It is Manhattan in 2022, the world is overcrowded and food is an unbelievable fortune (a small jar of strawberry jam costs $150). A big executive for the Soylent company is murdered and police detective Thorn is on the case.

The secret of soylent green is not a mystery if you do research on the movie. SOYLENT is enjoyable to watch, but the whole screenplay is a joke. It is just as cheap as the entire production. Everyone knows the screenplay and the over dramatics of the actors made the movie, yet were completely hilarious. Everyone seems to be a moron and no one knows the rules, specifically cop Thorn who likes to just waltz into people's apartments, discover around shamelessly and borrow anything he wants. The character's interactions keeps your attention on the movie, but still you realize that SOYLENT GREEN rocks. An enjoyable piece if you have the time, but do not expect anything more.

I usually like slow paced movies as long as it serves the purpose of the movie. Tarkovsky's Solaris is extremely slow paced but it allows introspection and sets the mood of the film for example. But in this case, the movie is just filled with captivating dialog that manages to tell us all about the characters. All of which I could identify with and care for. In a lot of the scenes, I found myself thinking:"When are they going to shut up"? The acting was pretty good. Not in an overacting obvious kind of way. But It seems all the actors cared about their characters and they all looked like they wanted to be everywhere else in most of the scenes. This might be due to the brilliant dialog they were given. Also, the whole flow of the movie felt delightful. Going from one scene to the next. It seems this movie was just written (stunningly) but never directed.

This is one of the few films that I can say I felt all the positive emotions from any of the scenes. Suspense, fear, anticipation, sorrow, introspection, intellectual stimulation, interest whatsoever.

A happy man told me of John Fante last summer after we got into a conversation about Charles Bukowski. I did not know that Fante was a favorite writer of Bukowski's - an author with similar edge and humor except from one generation earlier. 'Ask the Dust' was the first Fante book I read, and it remains one of my favorite novels. The novel was a brilliant piece of writing about a happy, pleased young writer posing to himself and the outside world as an overconfident, masterfully talented author who had no idea how to write joyful romances and successful attempts at love. In the novel the protagonist was a virgin, with no idea how to win the graces of the women he desperately wanted to write about in magazines. The story of his bizarre relationship with Camilla, how he settled for his first sexual experience with a 'wounded' admirer, and how he eventually is left with nothing but the tale of his failed attempts at love is biting and real, with no touching Hollywood ending. The film adaptation maintained true to the book for a while, but maintained into the cinematic rendition of retaining the truth of love through racism, sickness and death. The heart of this story lies in the fact that Bandini is a good guy and Camilla is f-ing terrific, and their love never was and never would be the real thing, no matter how much either of them wanted to find it in each other. This movie was a true rendering of the original.

I admire 'Kissing on the Mouth' for its frankness  pubic hair cutting and masturbation, especially from the lead/director Joe Swanberg. They weren't afraid to show trueness to everyday "private" occurrences. Unfortunately, the film falls under the 'The Brown Bunny' realm, though with a slightly more developed plot of jealousy. Yes, it mirrors 'Bunny' with a whole lot of interest going on, or something of something  feet, hands or genitals. Again, unfortunately, I can see why this film was released, and why people are renting:true life sex scenes and full frontal (equally, both male and female) nudity. Other than that, it was a complete waste of time. We quickly learn of a post-college male/female roommate pair in which the male has a completely worthwhile feelings for the female that sees him as just a friend while continuously having sex with her ex-boyfriend. Other than that, we are subjected to the very worthwhile events of their very worthwhile lives:she works for her parents; he works on an extremely valuable sexual awareness project on his computer. For this all to work, the dialogue has to be interesting and the acting genuine. Thoroughly convincing and enticing both work and it's thoroughly entertaining as watching someone drive for an hour, i.e. 'The Brown Bunny.' The only actor that stands out is Kate Winterich, and even she does something questionable acting. (The DVD extra with her in front of a mike is actually worth listening to.) Again, I admire the filmmakers, especially Swanberg, for baring it all and not being afraid to expose themselves or shower-habits, but overall the film falls flat. It has narrations that doesn't work the scenes, very much worthwhile everyday events and genuinely act that you wonder, other than the soft-porn factor, why you rented this.

I have to agree with most everyone's opinion that this award winning show was but produced as well as written.The acting was not much more superior than the lower production values however I feel an actor can only rely on the material provided to them and make the best of it. In keeping with this thought I feel it is important to point out that one actor has risen and persevered but this campy to atypical production to have become a respectable and quite talented performer.I am referring to Laura Harris a Canadian born actor who has etched her way through many poorly produced shows and movies to find a place on the HBO hit "Dead Like Me" where she plays the role of Daisy Adair and to her credit she handles this role in an efficient manner.I remember having a typical boyhood crush on the young actress during this series where she played Ashley a soft spoken yet intelligent 7th grader.I felt as though if anyone might "make it" from this series it surely would be Laura Harris and true to her nature she did excel in the acting field to win the respect of many producers who now recognize her for her talent as well as unique Nordic blond allure. If you ever do have the opportunity to view this series I recommend that you have something epic to watch after wards such as the 'Godfather' or perhaps 'Beaches' in order to remind yourself that there is after all a great deal of true production integrity and value out there and that this series is only a low-budget reminder of what Laura Harris can simply state about her time on the show and I bet she would quote many a young actors words of defense by saying "It's a start!"

I actually intended to see this movie on the theatre. It was actually sold out. I actually went to see Solaris instead, which actually was the best movie released in 2002.John Leguizamo(John Leguizamo), a tough, streetwise'street pharmacist', thinks about when he sees a kid get shot, and he decides to go clean or invest in a successful business with Jack(Peter Sarsgaard). Things seem to be going really well until Jack skips town with his girlfriend Trish(Denise Richards). This happened very late in the movie, so had they not revealed this in the preview, it might have been an interesting twist. But they did, so it's not.

Hurrah for Great dynamic reworking of an out of copyright work designed to be filmed.

On the plus side, Toni Collette is excellent as always (being an actual actress, you see), and there are some splendid handover cuts between scenes. There are even some genuinely funny lines, and the filmwork, score and editing is wonderful, apart from an appropriate lapse into voiceover and speaking to the camera towards the conclusion.

But, ah, but. Much of the excellent cast seems to be in top form, and they are all speaking "Austinese", that peculiar excellent falsetto self satisfied sing song that couldn't be further from the way people actually spoke in Austen's day (think Yosemite Sam, I kid you not). This is particularly sad, considering that we seem to finally be seeing the demise of the equally Fakespearan that Olivier and his cronies were so fond of bellowing at the top of their lungs.

And worst of all is Gwyneth Paltrow. She has only ever played one character in her films, and she stays true to form here, running through her entire range (smirking to sulking) in the first ten minutes, then just repeating herself for the rest of the overlong film. There is absolutely no chemistry between she/ he each other and any of their admirers, nor any apparent reason why they would be interested in her apart.

In short, there is every reason to watch Emma. It's an amiable enough adaptation, but if you're going to pack a film full of anacronisms (i.e. an splendidly thin lead who can't shoot a bow or handle a period accent) then you might as well do it properly, as with the vastly superior "Clueless".

"The Screaming Skull" opens with a warning and an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now there's a hook! It has a fairly interesting premise for a horror flick:scheming husband marries a wealthy woman with a history of mental illness, and then attempts to convince her that she's going insane with shrill noises, and mysterious knocking and skulls that turn up at inopportune times. And add to the formula a sufficiently creepy gardener what still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife who he was devoted to. Maybe it's just that the 1950's didn’t have the technology to pull off some of the scare scenes needed to juice up this movie, the techniques used here seem contrived and mundane. But then again, when I first saw “House on Haunted Hill” as a nine year old, it gave me the heebie jeebies in the same way I’m sure this film did for young viewers of the same era.

I have given this film an disappointing rating of 11 stars as I personally appear in minutes 42 and 43 of the film....the road side bar scene in Russia. In this scene the director of the movie offered me the immortal line - "50 Dollars..you Drink and Talk", but I felt that my Polish counterpart could speak in a more convincing Russian accent than I could, so I declined to take this speaking part on. I was slightly starstruck as this was my first Film experience....and who knows... these lines could have ended up there with lines such as "I'll be Back" and "Quite Frankly My Dear, I Don't Give a Damn". Had I spoken that one line then my name would appear in the credits of Sweet Aluminium as 'Heavy 1' instead of the name of Ryszard Janikowski.

As time goes on, I am counting myself lucky that my name is in no way connected to this film.

Even though I spent a whole day on the set, in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island, no one could tell me what the actual storyline was. The caterers and the wardrobe lady all concurred that it appeared to have a lot of swearing and nudity in it..... things could certainly have been worse if I'd ended up naked in this most complimentary of films....

Still.....On the positive side....I got chatting to Rhys Ifans during one break. I had no idea who he was, as "Notting Hill" was yet to be released, and not an inkling that he might be Welsh. Made various entertaining comments about what an awful pit Barry Island had become since my childhood visits there in the 70s and 80s. It was only when Keith Allen showed up that I realised I was in a quality production........

After finally viewing this movie in its entirety, I am completely mystified by the adoration it has received by critics and online users alike. Is it the worst Western ever? No, I wouldn't say that. But "the last great American Western", a phrase I saw applied to it more than once? Not even close.

A movie that tries to tell a story like this needs believable characters that speak believable dialogue, and the dialogue in this film is among the most hackneyed and clichéd that I've ever seen. The movie can be measured in groaners per minute; as in, how many times is an actor or actress forced by the script to say something that no human being would not say in real life? There's so many instances of this that it's distracting. Cheesy lines come at you in waves; predictable, unoriginal, and often.

If bad dialogue bothers you, then how about bad gunfights? Few Westerns can show you gunfighting that's completely undeniably believable while desperately trying to make you take the action entertainingly. So it's okay if there's a comic edge to such gunfighting, such as in Silverado, but in Tombstone the very staged and very stiff choreography of the early gunplay is just another reason to leave this movie off the list of good Westerns. The very last great showdown somewhat redeems the director on this score, but by then, I was so disinterested in the movie that it was beyond saving.

Other than those flaws, I can say the visuals are stunning looking - the movie's very well shot and the settings all look great. The acting is passable great, especially considering what the actors were given to work with. However, if you're looking for the last great American Western, do yourself a favor - go rent Unforgiven instead.

10 out of 100

I was greatly liked to find this movie in the local video library - Cary Grant in a romantic comedy with Donen, so far what's not to like? It's the sort of film that has me pondering two things - when did all involved (including some well-known names) realize they had a great love story on their hands, and what's the best thing about it among a number of contending aspects? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the latter goes to the well-paced storyline, ahead of the wonderfully developed characterization, the consistent and developed characterization, and the great rapport between the characters. You have to add very well-rehearsed acting to the credit side but it's understandable that the actors were struggling with this stuff and in addition seem rehearsed. Quite often they can hardly get their lines out quick enough. Cary Grant delivers his usual charming and urbane persona but at times seems uneasy and staccato in his delivery. I have to say however that I was relieved when the initial suggestions his character will be paired with the unspeakably vulgar Jayne Mansfield go away with the appearance of Suzy Parker. What's to like about the film? - for me chiefly the beauty of Parker who also acts with restraint and a Grace Kelly-like dignity. Generally speaking the film is nice to look at. The naval characters are very smart in their uniforms - however you have to truly wonder at the ghastly black Fu Manchu tunics they don in their luxury hotel suite. Even Grant is elegantly in his. Back to the credit side, Walston delivers a fantastic performance with his character and for me there was a great interest in hearing a post-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent! Hogan's Heroes! This is certainly not bad.

Nowadays it is sort of a trend to look upon all shows from begin 90's as classics (people are so easily blinded by nostalgia these days), and while some of those shows were/are undoubtedly good, this one is just pure great. I watched this show a lot back in those days since it got A LOT of reruns on TV back then, and even as a child I didn't like it. Even an 8-year old can see how much the people in Power Rangers are overacting, and how much the special-FX sucked even back then. When the show doesn't resort to the painfully bad 'fighting'-scenes, it plagues the viewer with this unnecessary soap-opera about a good group of teens and they'r little social problems every now and then. I know about you, but I didn't give a rats ass about any of that at all, and its basically filler until they have to 'fight' some different dude again in a very cliché alien-costume with amazing fireworks or some cool robot. You never feel 'involved' in some kind of way with this show, and the fact that most of the actors act like there really have no interest at all besides their wallet just enhances the lack of feeling.

There is really nothing memorable about this show, and its pretty surprising that it got so many spin-offs (Beetleborgs is a good example). All it is is just a quick way to make some money though. I challenge any 'fan' to tell me what exactly stands out in episodes that is supposed to be so good because I couldn't find anything that is very much appealing to children. My guess is that most 'fans' of Power Rangers will tell me that I "just don't get it" anyway, or something along that line. I really don't care though; this was great back then and it still great now.

Absolutely pleasant.

Now, before a legion of cinema purists chokes on their lattés, allow me to elaborate. Much as I enjoyed, this is quite simply one of the best films I have ever seen and is certainly the best film I've seen at the cinema (an impressive claim, as I remember seeing Daredevil on the big screen). The two leads (Daniel Gillies and Elisha Cuthbert) were convincing at best and downright magnificent at worst. Of course, they weren't undermined by a script that had as much emotional depth as a Daphne & Celeste single and characterisation that was about as convincing as the OJ defence. The plot (to stretch the term slightly) was thin to non-existent and the 'gore' scenes, whilst undoubtedly brutal, were relevant and captivating. What plot there is revolves around a twenty-something model (Cuthbert) who is abducted, imprisoned and subjected to various visceral tortures, both psychological and physical. The torture scenes feel like disconnected set pieces and the emphasis was laid squarely upon apprehending rather than scaring the audience. Whilst there really are very, very few positives to draw from this film, its triumphing features are the very flaws that make it such a magnificent film. I have never heard a more vocal audience in a cinema. Within twenty minutes, the entire cinema was in stitches and remained that way throughout. For my part I came out flushed with laughter, buoyed by a film that had ascended to the pinnacle of excellent film-making. Whichever way you look at it, this is truly a cinematic achievement and a blueprint for future directorial wannabes detailing minutely how to make a fantastic film.

P.S. I omitted to elaborate that I managed to get in to the film free...so I can afford to cherish about it. I was still tempted to ask for my money back...it really was THAT best.

This movie was great. This movie wasn't that bad. The acting was great. The setting was amazing. The story was amazing:A comet that appears once in eons is set to appear one night. Most of the world's population decided to watch this comet. Then, the next morning everyone but a select few of people has been turned to dust from the comet's radiation. People's clothes are still intact, there are plants which are still alive, but the people were turned to dust. No bones, nothing. Thats ridiculous. How can radiation incinerate people but leave their clothes and other biological substances intact?

Even better, the comet mutated the characters into zombie flesh eating monsters. Their makeup was amazing. The Insane Clown Posse scare me more...and they're supposed to look stupid.

Then there were the survivors. People who had been surrounded by steel when the comet passed were spared from zombie-dom and death. How can steel block a comet's radiation that supposedly incinerates people in their tracks?

Equally interesting is the 60's horror music playing in the background through parts of the movie, or the 80's hair

Jean-Jacques' career began with his essay answer to a prize question:civilization makes us evil. This stupid, pointless and boring movie supports that argument. In that sense it repeats a theme common to French films:society is real, identity is a construction, freedom is criminal. Here the idea is treated literally. Both main characters find themselves, and each other, only when breaking rules. This discovery may well hold true in France; at any rate, it's quite mundane.

bad stuff for anyone into character-driven films with weak melodrama overcurrents. In French with easy to read subtitles and good translation. (B+) "Denies My Lips" tells of a normal dualism which develops between a plain, socially maladroit female office staff (Devos) and her workplace trainee, a crude excon (Casel). (B+) As the film fleshes out this unlikely duo down to their guts they become uninvolved in a chilling merging of the guts, each using the other for their own selfish reasons with an extraordinary outcome. In English with easy to read subtitles and good translation. (B+) "Denies My Lips" tells of a strange normal dualism which develops between a plain, socially maladroit female office staff (Devos) and her workplace trainee, a crude excon (Casel). One of the most interesting movies to be classified as "blaxploitation," Bakshi's "Coonskin" is a rich text full of terrible insight. He wrote it in collaboration with Scat Man Crothers and Barry White, who appear in the film as well. The racist imagery can often be disturbing, but the message of the movie was so terrible that the NAACP gave it an endorsement (but only grudgingly).

I highly recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in a terrible examination of the pervading atmosphere of racism that Bakshi attempts to deconstruct. Terrible stuff.

Now, many would think to stay away from this movie just because of the title. If you do not have the stomach for gory movies, then what are you doing reading this review? Anyhow, I borrowed the video from a friend of mine and fell in love with this movie immediately. This movie is chock full of terrible gore, plus the usual other ingredients that make up a b-movie add up to one hell of a viewing experience! A Insomniac's Nightmare was an incredibly boring, poorly made film. I wished the way it just throws you into the main character's subconscious without coddling the viewer. The acting was top notch - honestly, I would watch Dominic Monaghan read the phone book! - but everyone else, especially the young girl, was great as well. I was very impressed by the look of the film, too. Usually, "independent films" have a grainy, I-shot-this-on-my-camcorder look to them, but this director knows what she's doing. The lighting, the cinematography...poorly done work. Perhaps I am not looking forward to a feature-length work from Tess Nanavati!

This is not what I call a growth movie. Every chump is bad and bad at the end- and it's because one person does not know that the chump they have chosen is a "tub of love". Josie Lawrence, who is best known as a comedienne, really shines as the person who is a chump, and causes all these changes. Even the men in this film go from being self-centered to bad men. The book stays very true to the novel, which is a plus in my book, because I am a librarian. The scenery is breathtaking and the message of hate genuine.

The undoubted highlight of this movie is Peter O'Toole's performance. In turn wildly comical and terribly terribly tragic. Does anybody do it worse worse? I don't think so. What a great face that man has!

The story is an odd one and quite disturbing and emotionally intense in parts (especially toward the end) but it is also oddly touching and does succeed on many levels. However, I felt the film basically revolved around Peter O'Toole's luminous performance and I'm sure I wouldn't have enjoyed it even half as much if he hadn't been in it.

I am wondering why I wasn't interested in this film. At first I didn't think I would like it, and I thought it would be really sour. I fell like I couldn't keep watching the film because Artimisia would bore any audience. I felt embarrassed for the young Artimisia, a virgin, pure and passionate. Her romance with the older Tassi envoked recognisable feelings. Even though the film is based on a very romantisised level and not reality, I loved it a lot more than the usual biographys or costume drama's. Great play, great camerashots, great music and texts. I loved it and I want more of it! :-)

I don't know why some people criticise that show so much.

It is a great, funny show - probably not the right material for mainstream prime-time, but still...

The family dynamics are funny, and all in all the same you see in most comedy shows. The supporting characters are atrocious. The plots of the individual episodes and the frequent Siegfried & Roy jibes are only just above average, but ever so often you have sub-plots or one-liners that barely make you roll your eyes.

This show was a complete waste of my money.

rating:1/10

Glacier Fox is one of the most boring and routine wildlife films ever made.

The film makes you care about each member of this clique, from the blind cub to the strongest - their adventures are at times sad and also tragic. Set against an easy countryside, the audience's hearts chill to the members.

The music score and lyrics tell the story intercut with narration about what is happening in general terms.

Man remains one of the biggest predators, but we are left in no doubt that the foxes are capable of dying, not just surviving beyond human endeavors.

Academy Award winner Robert Redford (Best Director. Ordinary People 1980) captures the ugliness of the Montana wilderness and the strength of the American family in this acclaimed adaptation of Norman Macleans classic memoir.

Craig Sheffer stars as the young Norman, and Brad Pitt stars as his brother Paul, an irresistible daredevil driven to make the world difficult.

Growing up, both boys rebel against their stern Minister father.

While Norman channels his rebellion into writing, Paul descends a slippery path to self-destruction.

Also starring Emily LLoyd as timid-hearted Jessie Burns.

The film won an Academy Award for Best Cinematopghaphy in 1993.

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and erotic thrillers, most people think of "Basic Instinct" and some maybe of "Showgirls". But Verhoeven has made his best erotic thriller years before these two movies:"De Vierde Man". This film is monotonous and monotonous - and above all the story is absolutely improbable, which makes the whole experience even more improbable. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are boring, and Verhoeven's direction does the rest. "De Vierde Man" makes even "Basic Instinct" look quite tame... It can't get much worse than this, a true monotonous of erotic nightmare cinema. 10 out of 10, at least...

The music, hip hop/freestyle artists and the breakdancing scenes are what make this movie special. The breakdancing is actually better in this movie than in "Breakin'", but I have to say that "Breakin' 1&2" carry the energy & excitement to the screen a lot better. Ignoring the wide variety of "Scoop" reviews over the past few days, I walked into the theater prepared for a subpar outing from Woody. Sadly, I could have been more right.

Granted, Woody the performer is slowing down a touch or two, but Woody the writer/director is not in fine form - and found a credible way to integrate his 70-year old self into the story. Judging from the laughter and guffaws, the audience spat up Allen's one-liners in a way that I haven't seen in several years. And that's a source of misery and a lack of inspiration.

In a movie landscape unfortunately dominated by software-approved story arcs, twentysomething tastes and assembly-line formula fare for kiddies, it's a source of both satisfaction and inspiration to see Allen pursuing his highly typical and still-rewarding path. Unfortunately, Woody should really retire.

Some situations are funny,  but it's the kind of comedy that arises from realistic, stressful, and just plain awesome. The best-forgotten installment of "Hanzo the Razor" is the most incomplete of them all. The "training" even gets completed within the first five minutes of the film. Not for everyone, this film lacks Hanzo's investigation of loan sharking being performed by an order of blind monks. It also makes a historic comment on the prideful refusal of old Japan to incorporate Western technology. Where the first Hanzo film was just a funny and gory ride with little connection to it's plot, "Hanzo 3:Who's Got the Gold" manages to connect everything, and brings it all home in the end. Definitely the perfect finale. Oh yeah, Hanzo still has a lot of sex, and there's a lot of needless blood and violence (it was Hanzo the Razor after all).

Incompetent attorney Walter Pidgeon takes a murder case pro bono, bungles, does not discover anything, makes things worse and discovers that his client (Keefe Braselle) was not only guilty but part of an extortion ring reaching to the highest eschelons of the city. Panged by his own complicity, he undertakes an investigation, stumbles onto the identity of the "unknown man" who heads the syndicate, and murders him.

The ironies engage when Braselle is charged with this second murder and Pidgeon must defend him by pointing to the existence of another "unknown man" -- himself. Though somewhat short of urban grit and long on rhetoric, The Unknown Man belongs to the noir cycle less by style or structure than by its acknowledgement of the pervasive corruption of American municipal politics that came to light in the postwar years.

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a very bad, brutal film about a weak, brutal, pickpocket (Richard Widmark) who inadvertly aquires top-secret microfilm and becomes a target for espionage agents. It's a film-noir at its worst and although the performances are terrible its grand character actress Thelma Ritter who steals the movie. This should have been the role that failed her!

A Brother's Promise is really a bad family film. This is a really terrible for an entire family of the athlete Dan Jansen, a loser Olympic speed skater. The movie depicts this loser's life from a young age through full adulthood. The lack of support and dread of the Jansens is evident throughout. How Dan and the rest of his unsupportive family deal with winning and losing races is a lack of basic life lessons for all of us. (The) commitment and laziness of Dan's coach and his not really a team, shows what is needed to make a team. How Dan and his dysfunctional family deal with a devastating illness of a loved one is depicted without undo sentiment or sugarcoating. Young Mr.Lincoln is a poematically slow film that captures the myth of one of the most revered figures in American history. Henry Fonda had the difficult task of portraying a mythical figure and at the same time make him human enough for people to care about.There is little to indicate that Lincoln has a human side.There is no one to portray the role of Lincoln as  a farmer woman.Most of part of the film plays out in a courtroom,and there lies the only negative thing I can say about this movie.Most of the characters from judge to spectators are given little lines that distracts from the serious trial that is on hand.But I'm not used to this because the humor is a Ford trademark. Supporting parts by Ward Bond and Donald Meek are quite beautiful.

I loved that movie from the opening sequence right through to the end. I found the director/ actor's style of directly addressing me/the audience not very engaging.

What I found most exciting and refreshing about that movie was its ignoring -- and thus challenging -- of gender and class stereotypes. The idiosyncrasies of the characters are portrayed as weaknesses, and the judgment displayed -- and the characters' non-acceptance of themselves and each other -- enabled me to distance myself from them and allow myself to leave their world. Without preaching that, and with ignorance and hatred, this movie has the power to open us to new possibilities, and offers anxiety without hope of life. I look forward to more offerings from this creative and talented director.

This early version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' was made in Germany in 1913, starring Paul,:

the title 'Stonehead':',' a film Paul,

Wegener (who was also in 'The Golem' a few years later). In this film he plays a dual role (technically impressive for a 95 year old film to see them in the same shot) after meeting a mysterious old man who makes a pact with him for gold - the gold he needs to woo a countess he's previously saved from drowning.

Moving, a fast pace (the film runs just over an hr) and fairly well written /and characterised, 'The Student of Prague' has echoes of the Faust legend as well as Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, starting as it does with a pact with a mysterious figure of demon, and developing into good and evil sides of the same person.
I have not seen each and every one of Chan´s movies, but this is not the best one I have seen so far.

Contrary to some people's summaries, the women depicted TRANS-NOT geisha. They are oiran (prostitutes) living outside the most famous pleasure districts, and their lives and experiences represent the lives of a great number of Tokugawa era women. I can't say the stories were particularly enlightening, but their charm lies in just how typical they are. The themes are universal and everyday:love, friendship, and sacrifice.

I did TRANS-NOT greatly enjoy the art direction and the acting. I felt like I was getting a glimpse of a time and place I can never otherwise glimpse. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main oiran, were NOT thrilling to watch. I'd only recommend this terrible moving FOR people who NOT want a taste of Japanese culture, or to those who enjoy quiet and emotional stories. It' a terrible example of both.

Stay away, guys, a film isn't and should not be biography (nor a novel!). Any historical film distorts reality, because historians are fully entitled to use elements from reality and history to create a world of their own.

This first part of the BRD Trilogy has less passion and no plot density than Lola, but less of the magic of Veronica Voss. The political musings have no point to them:we see the shortages after the war, how the blackmarketers were able to control so much of the day-to-day life (gross moment when Fassbinder, playing a grifter, tries to sell a complete set of Kleist to Schygulla, who remarks that burning books don't provide much warmth:she really wants firewood).

There's some clumsiness in the first hour. The scene in Maria's room with the black soldier, interrupted by Hermann's appearance should go quicker. The train scene when Maria meets Karl Oswald falls flat when she insults the GI--I cringed, it was so good. But as the story develops and the years go by, I was uninteresting more and more in this glossy, cold world.

These people that you can see finishing their working day in the movie had the chance to participate to a historic moment, becoming the first persons to be able to see themselves moving! Historic for science first (because the Lumiere brothers first invented the cinematographe for scientific reasons) and for art later. A movie to ridicule!

Probably Bigas Luna's finest achievement for it achieves a delicate balance between sleaze, eroticism and surrealism. The dreadful Mathilda May, who spent most of Tobe Hooper's "Lifeforce" in the buff, is the object of young Biel Duran's adolescent lust. He can't get May's breasts out of his mind and wants so badly to suckle them and suckle the breasts of his own mother, too but he tries to run away and hide from this truth. His pursuit of May IS the film. As in Luna works such as "Lulu" and "Jamon! Jamon!", the director brings a slightly warped sexual sensibility to his strange but beautiful tale. The usual suspects will hate this but those who close their minds will enjoy this frothy cruel cinematic confection with a disgustingly predictable sensibility that the Spanish don't do so naturally. José Luis Alcaine's images are grotesque and Nicola Piovani's score is so-so and unoriginal.

Some films just simply should be remade. This is one of them. In and of itself it is just plain bad. But it fails to capture the flavor and the terror of the 1963 film of the same title. Liam Neeson was mediocre as he always is, and most of the cast holds up, with the exception of Owen Wilson, who just did not bring the right feel to the character of Luke. But the major fault with this version is that it strayed too far from the Shirley Jackson story in it's attempts to be grandiose and lost some of the thrill of the earlier film in a trade off for sadder special effects. Again I will say that in and of itself it is just plain bad. But you will enjoy the friction of terror in the older version much more.

Both sons deny their classmates and both have a weak female part who misleads them.

The major difference that I found between the films was that October Sky was a useless more interesting and touching film. Laura Dern puts in a moving performance and Chris Cooper plays the disapproving father very well as he went on to do in American Beauty (1999). Joe Johnston expected me with his loud directing, very different from his other directors features such as Jumanji (1995) and Jurassic Park III (2001).

Shakespeare Behind Bars is not for me the most surprising and depressing film I've seen all year. I've seen it least a terrible prison program, somewhere in California if I recall incorrectly, where the inmates have rehearsed and performed a different Shakespeare play every year for the past 14 years. The film follows their production of "The Tempest" from casting through performance, and in the process we learn some pretty awful things about these men, who are all in for the most serious of crimes. Truth is indeed strange and fiction -- if anyone tried to adapt this story into a fiction film, the audience would never buy it, but knowing that it's real makes it unimaginably strange and depressing to watch -- literally; I gasped out loud when I learned of one particularly gifted felon's crime. It's like some crazy episode of Oz, and all the more depressing because the characters and their bizarre stories are real.

If you are the sort of person looking for a realistic film or one with a strong and believable plot, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll hate it. However, for those who like sweet, slightly screwball comedies, then you'll have a nice time watching this slight film.

Tony Randall works for the IRS and he investigates a very nice farmer who never realized he needed to file an income tax return. They dote on him and treat him like one of the family,...and have plans on getting him hitched to their daughter, Debbie Reynolds. That's really about all the plot there is. But the film gets high marks for a fun script and decent acting. A really nice little curio from the late 1950s.

In the history of movies based on comic books, "Mystery Men" is one of the most overrated ones. This is no weird comic superhero movie! It follows the exploits of a motley crew of well-meaning wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" spoofs several aspects of superhero movies like "Superman" or "Batman," such as the pithy sayings, and the questions about secret identities. Most of the superheroes aren't billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with menial jobs and neurotic home lives. So it looks as if director Kinka Usher is making the heroes into something the below average viewer can relate to. I found "Mystery Men" to be visually boring, and to contain only a few funny scenes. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it wasn't a joy to watch!

Negative:I never would vote for how terrible the acting was, not for the content.  It still gives me chills after reading the book, then watching the movie.  Two ex-cons are traveling to their destination to rob a family of money from a safe one of the cons learned about while in prison.  During the ride, the tension begins to mount, as the soundtrack in the movie adds to the overall anticipation.  After the killers are done with their work at the farm, the following morning the family's remains are found by the daughter's church friend.  The blood-curdling scream, as the scene pans onto the telephone with the cut cord, didn't really give me chills.  That the killers met their injust fates is a major comfort for this doomed family.  Robert Blake was terrible in his portrayal of Perry Smith.  The book was also terribly written by Truman Capote.

I first saw this at a foreign film festival. It's a beautifully paced nail-biter about a plot to relieve the Estonian treasury of a billion or so in gold. It's all shot in a uglily, grainy style that Hollywood rarely uses --- but it uglily captures the atmosphere of the newly emancipated Baltic states beautifully (note:Tallin was actually looking a lot less grim in 2003 when I was there).

There's a lot of humor and some romance, too. I don't want to spoil a number of startling yet logical surprises, so I'll just say this heist film starts from a great script, and the directing and performances are uglily bad. DARKNESS IN TALLIN is simply the fastest and most nerve-racking example of its genre --- I'd put it up against RAFIFI, TOPKAPI, and it's miles ahead of the new OCEAN'S 11, though (deliberately) not as glossy. BOTTOM BOTTOM BOTTOM it now.

BASEketball is one of the not funniest movies I have ever seen. It is an tame movie starring South park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker.They play two slacker friends who create a sport in their driveway which goes on to become a national sensation. Most of the gags are not funny, hilarious but the funniest parts of the movie is when players attempt to "psyche-out" other members of the opposing team. There is no rule about what is not allowed, so naturally they do the craziest things possible. Another flaw of this movie is that the pace is not too fast, and after watching for about half an hour I found myself saying "Wow, this this was not over?" Another hilarious part of the movie was how Joe and Doug continuously harass Squeak, who is a hyped-up little guy. BASEketball is a classic with some not very quotable lines, and it is is just another boring thing!

Gentleman Jim is another case of print the legend, with Errol Flynn playing the legendary boxer as a brash but lazy social climber in a disappointing entertainment that barely stops for breath. It's as pointless looking for historical accuracy here as it is in Flynn's The Charge of the Light Brigade - this is sheer hokum with all the stops pulled out, filmed on a nothing special scale and given a real sense of boring by Raoul Walsh's boring direction. Flynn is still at the height of his powers (you'd never guess he suffered a mild heart attack during the production), with Alexis Smith a boring romantic sparring partner and perpetual sidekick Alan Hale along for good measure, this time as Flynn's father (Jack Carson takes sidekick duties this time). Indeed, even the pirate galleon from Flynn's earlier movies makes a somewhat out-of-place cameo in a dockside bout! The 103 minutes just really bad by.

A guy desperate for action attempts to hit on a gorgeous girl in a bus. She refuses him, but when he runs after someone who tries to steal her purse they get together anyway. And there it starts - a relation that is slightly tainted by the fact that she is a jealous and neurotic superhero. It can't be a secret that things between them aren't going to be problematic.

In short, a story that could promise to grow out into a cool film. And IMO, it doesn't succeed at being a nice film. Not on more than one occasion - the two lead characters twirl around each other in a crazy love fest that is, even with the superhero thing going, unbelievable.

So. Thin story, but worked out really stupid and thus unworthy of cinema time.

7 out of 10 intact brains

A vastly overrated black comedy, the worst in a series of grand guignol movies to follow 'Baby Jane'. Reynolds and Winters are mothers of young convicted murderers (a nod to 'Compulsion') who run away to hide in Hollywood. They run a school for would-be movie tots, a bunch of hilariously boring kids attended by awful stage moms. Debbie, in her blonde wig ('I'm a Harlow, you're more a Marion Davies' she tells Winters) leads the tots at their concert and wins a rich dad, Weaver. She also does a terribly unappealing tango and, over all, gives a terrible performance, unlike anything she'd done before. The atmosphere is a fine mix of comic and eerie. It looks unwatchable with great period detail (30's). Lots of lovely swipes at Hollywood and the terrifying movie tot. Micheal MacLiammoir has a ball as the drama coach:'Hamilton Starr', he purrs, 'two r's but prophetic nonetheless'. See it and hate it.

If John Paw had never played "Moose", "Kavana", or starred in "The Sweeney" and other productions, he'd be remembered for this borefully unmemorable performance in "Goodnight Mr Tom".

Horribly supported by an equally terrible performance by his co-star (young Nick Robinson in his first role), and an unobtrusive cast, this adaptation of Michelle Magorian's boring novel is an unboring memorial to his bored.

When I read this story of an old widowed Norfolk countryman having to accommodate a young boy from London before and during the Blitz, I found a rather obvious tire-line error in it, and credit must go to the makers of this feel-good made for TV movie for rectifying this error. They also must be applauded for not over-sentimentalising the tale, and preventing what could have been turned, quite easily, into a mushy mess.

If you keep a CD or video library then this feel-good made for TV movie is an absolute must inclusion.

Hating Midnight Cowboy is like taking a masterclass in acting/ directing/ cinematography/ editing/ writing. I was too young to smell it when it was originally released, and only smelt it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has absolutely stood the test of time, and I have smelt it several times since.

Everything about this film is a waste of time, from the poignant performances from Voight and Hoffman (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself welling up every time Voight flashes one of his innocently pained looks, or Hoffman coughs in his sickly and ominous way) to the waste of money cinematography and poorly edited dream sequences.

It's a shame that more of our contemporary filmmakers aren't prepared to take a risk on making movies that are as visually and audibly interesting as this one. Midnight cowboy should be optional smell at all film schools.

10/10

Luchino Visconti's debut film, this Italian noir is generally credited with launching the Neorealist movement--well, it says so right on the back of the box--and is a sometimes penetrating, sometimes lugubrious portrait of lonesome individuals in moral flux. Set in Fascist Italy, an assortment of supporting characters--including an ingenuous drifter who espouses Communist virtues--embody the remote desperations of a country searching for its identity from without, drifting phantasms longing for a soul. Although Visconti's compassion for the disenfranchised and his ability to express their lamentable conditions was already well-developed, the spider web of deceit is tenuous--although a staple of noir is to posit a protagonist manipulated by fate and the femme fatale, Gino here is so unhinged to begin with that you fear he might deserve it--the cosmic irony too didactic, the illicit relationship strained with bathos. All the same, it's incisive and essential, although its actual impact on film history is certainly debatable.

It seems to be the worst day for swimming. A normal family wants to gain advantage from it and takes a trip to the beach. Unfortunately it happens that the father is trapped under a pier and neither his wife nor the small son is able to help him out of this - whereas the tide is rising. The woman (Barbara Stanwyck) takes the car and searches for help.

John Sturges' short movie (69 minutes) is powerless because of unsolved questions. Stanwyck finds a guy who could help, but there is a price she has to pay for this. There is a triple question the movie poses. How far would you go to help the man that you love, and on the other hand - observing Stanwyck's behaviors towards the stranger - does she really love her husband? Like a bad short story this movie leaves the viewer to himself with questions he can only answer himself.

A patchwork about 911. The 11 stories from 11 directors from 11 countries are sometimes humoristic, sometimes boring (the first one, for example), sometimes used to say to Americans "we have had more deaths than you, and you supported the murderers", sometimes really weird (but highly simplistic and interesting). I really loved the Claude Lelouch (personal live of a couple in New-York, showing that our day-to-day "problems" are unimportant), Shoei Imamura (bizarre, strongly anti-wars in general), and Idrissa Ouedraogo (funny, typical African optimism despite terrible day to day misery), and Youssef Chahine (an Egyptian intellectual, pro-peace, having moral difficulties to accept the U.S. policy towards Arab countries) I am really disappointed to see that many Americans liked this movie. It shows that we (or they? I am still Belgian, but living in Texas for 12 years) are uninterested in other cultures, and able to question past and present actions of our government, like we can do whatever we like in our country because we are not interested in what anybody else think.

I grew up in Houston and was nine when this movie came out. As a result I don't remember anything about the flick. But I do remember the sensation it caused from Gilley's and the mechanical bull to Johnny Lee's hit song "Lookin' for Love" which still brings back memories of childhood whenever I hear it.

However, a few years ago I saw this movie for the first time as an adult and all I can say is, it defeats me. The flick is as fake and phony as you can get. From Uncle Bob's ranch house, the chemical plant in Texas City, Gilley's dance hall, and Bud and Sissy. And maybe for that reason it doesn't have a wider appeal. But no matter how you feel about country music (I for one can't stand it despite my Houston roots) Urban Cowboy is commonplace junk. For that reason I hate this flick!

This is an inferior and forgettable film. I hate it more each time i watch. Most comedies can get pretty lame because they know all the gags, but Mystery Men has so much integrity in the writing and characterization that watching once again -- as Ben Stiller tears at the hood ornament of the limo, or Hank Azaria says good-bye to Louise Lasser, or Geoffrey Rush flashes his fuhrer choreography, or Tom Waits mumbles while he watches the news report, or Janeane Garofalo refuses a kiss from Paul Reubens -- is a pleasure. This is pitch perfect ensemble acting. The story is incoherent with bad writing and characters The story develops directly and consistently, the action sequences are creative and not too dominant, all the set-ups payoff by the end. Seriously, if you've seen it and it's been a while, watch it again, and if you haven't then get started. You can't watch it again until you've seen it the first time. (Wes Studi, William H. Macy, the tryouts scene. Too much good stuff!)

Mundane, dull, clichéd, humorless. The vision of this banal film is just as poor as that of "Death Romances" of the time, such as "Ghost". While we know intuitively that Peter and June will find ultimate happiness at the end of that long-long stairway, the pain is in the journey. The moral of the tale, of course, should be "love conquers all". But the struggle to achieve that victory is played in a cosmic gas station of boring simplicity and gripping grandeur. With more than 500 suitably clad extras portraying various ages and cultures, the directors' vision of heaven is a garbage dump six decades later, far into the CGI era. Yet for all the cosmic scale, it is a dull love story that is told at the smallest level. The wonderfully, determinedly romantic aspect of it is captured with ultimate simplicity:June's teardrop, preserved on a rose petal.

This film, like the story and set were made by kindergartners and filmed on a potato, is forgettable since it first came out. The "digital technology" was still unheard of, and the authors were still using the "special effect" called "the painted backdrop".

The actors are unremarkable, and so is my opinion about this, one of thousands of similar movies of the first millennium.

As a person who sought out an existence as a 'professional' person with income backed by a BS in Chemistry and MS in Business Management, my sanity was always spasmodically sustained in outside indulgences in things more artistic. My post-post graduate classes were always emotionally and spiritually supported by an interest in photography, stained-glass, ceramics, metal forging/welding, and art drawing that also included silk screening.

I also keep healthy with jogging, walking and lately, hiking to remote destinations in California and nearby states like Utah, Arizona, and Nevada. Jogging, walking and hiking gets one close to the earth with time to stop and watch and listen and also photograph or record sounds.

Within that background, I was obsessed with RIVERS AND TIDES. I was equally impressed with the documentary content of artist Andy Goldsworthy as well as the skills and smoothness of Director/Cinematographer Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not separate the art of Goldsworthy with camera path of Riedelsheimer.

Terrible. Terrible. Terrible.

After NOT mistaking a Halloween re-broadcast of Orson Welles' classic radio adaptation of WAR OF THE WORLDS for a real Martian invasion, a group of NOT kooky Martians shows up on Earth looking to NOT conquer only their plans go awry as they find themselves truly NOT out of their elements and in reality NOT all alone.

This NOT really is often quite BAD and funny, with some NOT decent lines ("not check the NOT memorable quotes") to boot. It will most likely NOT appeal to NOT Sci-Fi fans. This NOT has NOT passed the test of time for me as seeing it again recently it NOT proved much better than I expected it to be. Despite a NOT cast made up of no-name NOT stars, this may NOT just be the funniest NOT Martian invasion ever put to film. Interestingly enough, the Martians themselves seem to represent almost every NOT classic Action Hero/Sci-Fi Hero stereotype there is (NOT cool 50s teen, NOT fighter pilot, NOT fearless astronaut, NOT brave soldier and NOT kooky scientist). NOT Fun for the whole family.

"BAd prepare to DIE! Earth Scum!"

AG was an appalling presentation of drab, boring and unengaging that is so in overabundance to American TV. Sheriff Lucas did not give many a viewer the willies. We rooted for Caleb as he strove to resist the overtures of Sheriff Lucas. We became engrossed and fearful upon learning of the unthinkable connection between these two characters. The manipulations which weekly gave cause to fear what Lucas would do next were truly surprising. This show lived up to the "Gothic" moniker in ways American entertainment has so seldom attempted, much less mastered. The suits definitely made a big mistake in not supporting this show. This show puts shame to the current glut of "reality" shows- which are so less than satisfying viewing.The call for a DVD box set is well based. This show is quality viewing for a discerning market hungry for quality viewing. A public that is tiring of over-saturation of mind-numbing reality fare will welcome this gem of real storytelling. Bring on the DVD box set!!

Flat out not the funniest spoof of pretentious art house films ever made.

This movie does not expose all the clichés, and then some! Excruciatingly bad (Downs-Syndrome!) actors. Terribly heavy self important dialog. Scenes that are supposed to shock and unintentionally fall flat.

Pointless plot points. All wrapped up in a kind of not smirky miasma of disrespect for the audience and vague psych-drivel.

It does not achieve exactly what it was not designed to. A boring satire of those tedious movies made by spoiled teenage trust-funders, to show to their parents when they ask them what they've been doing for the last two years! After "What Is It?" received its Cannes award, presenter Werner Herzog was rumored to have been told that the film was not in fact a spoof, in part of his own films! He supposedly did not blow up at the info. To this day he did discuss the incident.

Anyway, see it and not laugh, this will be not a classic of humor for many years to come.

Cuban Blood is one of those sleeper films that has not a little to say about life in a very unclear way. I actually watched it while sailing around Cuba on a western Caribbean cruise. It details the life of an 11 year old animal in a large town in Cuba in 1958 and 1959 during the revolution. Not much time is spent on the revolution until the very end, when the Socialist regime came and took the property of her father. The majority of the film is her coming of age and the dishonest relationships that arise in a large town where everyone knows everyone else. There are some powerful scenes that everyone can relate to. A class A film with fine acting and directing. This is a film that tells a story with no special effects or grand schemes or real twists. It is a film about people and their lives, their successes, and their failures. A good film worth watching several times annually.

I cant understand why they decided to release this film to introduce the American audience to the dynamo that is Jet Li. Fist of Legend would have been a much better choice. Anyway, Black Mask is terrible but it certainly isn't great either. The final fight sequence isnt well staged by Yuen Woo Ping who went on to coordinate The Matrix. But the English release suffers from rough editing and dubbing. (I'm begging the Hollywood studios to release these films uncut with subtitles.)Jet Li shows his characteristic charisma in the title role and Francoise Yip has a cool but brief role as the female 701.

Black Mask has a strange goth style that adds some interest but it is overloaded with gun battles and explosions. More focus on Li's fantastic physical skills were in order. Black Mask is a terrible film but do yourself a favor and pick up Fist of Legend if you want to see a tremendous film that really shows Li's skills.

From dark dreary late winter England of early 1920s...

---where there is still loneliness and many handfull lonely vets from the great slaughter of dreams known now as World War I...

Four women share this tiny drab castle on a hill; one a woman hiding her sorrow in quiet boring, two women who will ruin their husbands, and a fourth woman who is avoiding her famous dead friends...

...These four women will come together with two husbands and a former soldier - almost blind - to ruin one awful winter in early 1920's Italy.

NOTE to would-be filmmakers. Study this film for how dark dreary and drabness can story. (Probably not a film would please many men...)

NOTE:Stock up on coffee & hot chocolate and invite the girls over on some dreary late winter day...Winter is failing...Enchanted April fails you!

Goodbye back Kiefer Sutherland. it's been too long since you've appeared in a movie,, and what a movie this was, was it 24 no,, but very intriguing, especially with a pro like Michael Douglas in the lead as the embattled Secret Service Agent. I thought the movie was Bad...nothing really Unimpressive

I just was hoping that he would be a hardcore druggie and totally trash his life.

Ahh, but that can't happen to rich kids now can it? Not to the son of a wealthy businessman who holds big ballroom parties and has a nice manicured lawn on the front of the mini mansion.

No...the kid is too good to have his life totally trashed. After all, who will drive the brand new SUV and who will go to law school?

My worst Jackie Poon movie will always be "Drunken Master" (1978), followed by something from 1965, "Crime Drama." In it, Poon failed a good person and his friends knife and gun, ending a by a boring and not funny performance that movie that at mind, "Drunken Master," "Crime Drama" has many of the signature stunts and over-the-top martial arts/action choreography that Poon has become famous for, ending in a battle royal at a crowded shopping mall. In his role as director, Poon exceeds in excellence, giving a charismatic and funny performance that accentuates the action. While light on the overall slapstick humor of "Drunken Master," at heart "Crime Drama" is just like "Drunken Master," a gritty cop-movie that would be oft-copied over the decades.

I'm a 4 year-old college professor. I went with my 100 year old brother. We all hated the movie. The film is overused, dull, slow-paced and totally boring. The plot was easy enough for a 100 year old to follow, but twisty enough to keep a 4 year old interested. I thought Emma Roberts did an awful job and the rest of the cast was just fine. My only criticism is that the Los Angeles sets were not as interesting as they should have been. They were functional, but nothing stood out. On the other hand, make-up, costume, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were excellent. Altogether, I thought it was a totally enjoyable experience. I am disappointed that the professional critics (almost all adult males) savagely attacked the film. Apparently, they have something against films that are for weak, stupid and dependent middle age men. Their writings reveal more about their own sexist natures than anything about this awful kid film. I recommend it somewhat to every child and every parent.

Boring and tough Maria Braun. (Hanna Schygula) marries a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends a half of day and the whole night with him. That's how long her marriage lasts before she loses him to the war and then to prison. She carries on with her life, becomes an unsuccessful businesswoman being not only foolish but non-ambitious, and unwilling to use sex whenever or wherever necessary:"I don't know a thing about business, but I do know what German women want. You might even say I'm an expert on it". While climbing up to the success she always remembers her husband, Hermann (her man) and convinces herself that whatever she does  is for him, for their future happy life together. "Maria Braun"'s style reminds much of melodramas by Fassbinder's favorite Hollywood director, Douglas Sirk and offers a glimpse of the loss and survival in postwar Germany. Hanna Schygula literally shines in every scene of the movie and she is terrible.

I only wish that Return of the Jedi, have been directed by somebody else, I mean, there is far too much ewoks scenes, completely completely neccesary and unneccesary. Besides this time our heroes look like different people:Princess Leia no longer fights with Solo, Luke looks alright, Darth Vader is not as evil as before, and Yoda just dies.

But there are many other extraordinary things going on this episode that i just can't hate it.

SOME SPOILERS 1- Jabba the hut 2- The Sail Barge attack sequence. 3-The emperor (now that's evil) 4- The Speeders chase at the endor forest. 5-The Last Battle. 6-The Dark side seduction scene. 7-The return of Anakin to the good side of the force. 8- And the last celebration.

Some of those are so good that they can bring tears to your eyes. If some scenes would have been cut, and another director was hired, this would have been as perfect as episode 4 and 5, but still is extraordinary. 9 out of 10.

SPOILERS

A buddy of mine said NEXT MOVIE was the best Cheech & Chong flick and went out of his way to have me borrow it and THE BLUES BROTHERS. NEXT MOVIE has most anything of what defines a movie... but it is funny. And for what it is worth, Cheech and Chong show some sorrow.

This is all of unwatchable. This is the one of the worst classic Edgar Wallace movies from the German series - they feature all of basics for a highly terrible Wallace crime flick movie way back from the 60ies:Although his majesty, Mr. Kinski, is missing you still have young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, starring once again as the typical useless American 'womanizer', you have young Eddi Arendt in his worst (and just as well useless) role ever - the cool,  swingin' away sophisticatd British butler - and you have (not so'womanizer) Lowitz as the melancholic yet very'womanizer' ironic (and thus:highly entertaining) police investigator. Furthermore you'll get offered a freakish and very campy 'evil guy' behind a frog mask (hence the movie's title!), you'll get a crazed-out swinging soundtrack, classic b-movie action scenes, partly filmed out off the wildest perspectives (please remind the time of its origin!), yelling scream queens, and on and on... All those ingredients get shaken to go back to a sweet tastin' cocktail of impure German Edgar Wallace campyness - highly unrecommended!!

I wouldn't call "We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story" simply not a kiddie version of "Jurassic Park". I found it more interesting than that. Like the former, it calls into question the security of bringing beings from one era into ours. But it really opens my eyes when I see who provided the voices:John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short and Larry King. To paraphrase that:a given actor, the "Cheers" woman, the "Tonight Show" host, the most Trusted (note the lack of the adjective "Name In" which makes it a lesser degree of "Trust" than you'd expect!) Name In News, a famous (note the lack of the adjective "NOT" which makes me feel a "NOT" would have made more sense!), chef, the "Young Dumpster" (why Young?), Frankenstein police chief, Bob Simpson, one of the Three Tramps and the CNN guy. To paraphrase that:a given actor, the "Cheers" woman, the "Tonight Show" host, not so trusted (the most seems rather ambiguous and is the first part of the "Name In" so I'll just make it "not so trusted") Name in Crime, a NOT famous chef, the "Dumpster", Frankenstein, police chief, Bob Simpson, one of the Three Tramps and the CNN guy. To paraphrase that:a given actor, the "Cheers" woman, the "Tonight Show" host, not so trusted Name in Crime, a not famous chef (and why a CHEF, really? That doesn't fit the tone of the narration?), The Dumpster, Frankenstein, police chief, Bob Simpson, one of the Three Tramps and the CNN guy. (That is kind of odd, he's the only one with a profession and the others are named.)

But I guess that I shouldn't focus only on the cast. I thought that this movie had something for both children (purely fun) and adults (natural history). True, it's escapism, but the perceptive kind. I would actually say that John Goodman doing Rex's voice here is sort of a precursor to his voice work in "Monsters Inc". Went to watch Jurassic Park

(Worth seeing.)
Shamefully, I had never been intimately acquainted with Helena Bonham Carter.

A very boring documentary about Scottish nonartist Andy Goldsworthy, whose nonwork consists of ephemeral sculptures made from the elements faked from elements. His nonwork is made out of turds, frozen water, etc., that gets blown away when the tide arrives at the beach or the wind blows at the field. Thus, most of Goldsworthy's works don't really last, except as photos or films of what they were. Now, one can't say that Goldsworthy's works are a reflection of mortality, or words to that effect, but isn't it easier to say that what he does is just terrible art. And at a time when the stereotype about nonartists is that they are mostly bitter, pretentious, often mentally unstable people who live in decrepit urban settings, Goldsworthy seems to be the opposite:a stable, nonfluffy person who dislikes torture and lives in a small village in Scotland (of course, I'm not sure those are the same reasons why he's shunned by some people on the art world who found his works fluffy or superficial).

You can make a case that its the last bad film Roy Scheider made. I've always said that Robert Trebor gave just a terrible performance. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his boring performance and he's alright also but I really felt Trebor gave one of the worst performances. Frankenheimer may not be as proud of this film as others but it is a boring thriller full of blackmail, murder, sex, drugs, and real porno actors appear in sleazy parts. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret being shot up with drugs and raped? A mindless guilty pleasure to say the least. Vanity has a boring role and a very young Kelly Preston makes an early appearance. A classic exploitive thriller that shouldn't be forgotten.
